events.id: Gong Bath at Vogelmorn Hall, Wellington-13 Vennell Street, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Gong Bath at Vogelmorn Hall, Wellington
events.venue: 13 Vennell Street, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.long_description:
*Limited door sales for $25*
*Please bring a yoga mat, pillow, eye mask and blanket - or whatever it is you need to feel most warm and comfortable *
Discover the transformative effects of sound therapy with this 1-hour gong bath experience.
During this session, participants will be surrounded by the resonant vibrations of gongs, carefully designed to induce deep states of relaxation and calm. As you settle into the experience, allow the soothing tones to wash over you, releasing tension and promoting a sense of inner peace.
Scientific studies have highlighted the benefits of sound therapy, particularly gong baths, in reducing stress and promoting overall well-being. The rhythmic patterns and overtones of the gongs can help entrain brainwaves, leading to a meditative state and improved mental clarity.
Beyond the immediate effects, many participants report experiencing lasting benefits such as improved sleep, reduced anxiety, and enhanced mood following a gong bath session. By immersing yourself in the healing vibrations of the gongs, you can tap into a deeper sense of relaxation and rejuvenation.
Whether you're looking to unwind after a long day or explore new avenues of self-care, this 1-hour gong bath offers a unique opportunity to reconnect with yourself and find balance amidst the hustle and bustle of daily life. There will be cups of tea available afterwards to help us integrate and ground.
**THIS EVENT IS RESTRICTED TO 40 PEOPLE ONLY**
About Me
Erika is a musician and astrologer based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. She has 30+ years musical experience. Erika has an interest in the healing properties of sound for mental and physical wellbeing, which she currently explores through her gong bathing practice

Papua Niugini Tok Pisin Wik - Papua New Guinea Pidgin Language Week
Celebrate: 7 - 13 September 2025

The 2025 theme for Papua New Guinea Pidgin Language Week is 'Lukautim, strongim na kirapim tokples na pasin blo tubuna - Preserve, revitalise and promote our language and culture'.

events.name: SharePoint Online/2019 for End Users, 2-Day Training Course in Wellington
events.venue: 100 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Course Code: SPOEU Duration: 2 Days Audience: End-users Overview Attendees will leave at the end of this course with an understanding of the role SharePoint plays within an organisation, as well as all of the knowledge required to successfully navigate around and contribute to their SharePoint Online sites, and collaborate within their team and the rest of their organisation.
Module List Module 1: Introduction to SharePoint & Microsoft 365 Module 2: Finding Content Module 3: Working with Lists Module 4: Working with Libraries Module 5: Working with Publishing Features Module 6: Leveraging Social Content in the Business Click here for the full 'SharePoint Online for End Users' course outline

events.id: SharePoint Online/2019 for Power Users, 4-Day Training Course in Wellington-100 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: SharePoint Online/2019 for Power Users, 4-Day Training Course in Wellington
events.venue: 100 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Course: SPOPEU Duration: 4 Days Audience: End Users Microsoft Course: 55215 Overview This course delivers the complete site owner story from start to finish in an engaging and practical way to ensure you have the confidence to plan and create new sites or manage your existing sites, whether you're using SharePoint Online through Microsoft 365, or SharePoint 2019 on-premises.
Your goal is to learn how to make SharePoint relevant to your team by using a sites functionality to help you share information and collaborate with your colleagues.
During the class you will also learn best practices and ‘what not to do’ as you watch live, interactive demonstrations and put theory into practice with hands on exercises.
Module List Module 1: Introduction to SharePoint Module 2: Finding Content Module 3: Working with Lists Module 4: Working with Libraries Module 5: Working with Publishing Features Module 6: Leveraging Social Content in the Business Module 7: Site Owner Responsibilities Module 8: Creating and Managing Sites Module 9: Site Customisation Module 10: Permissions and Security Module 11: Creating & Managing Lists & Libraries Module 12: Advanced Document Management Module 13: Power Platform Integration Module 14: Creating & Managing Content Types Click here for the full 'SharePoint Online for Power Users' course outline Click here for the full 'SharePoint 2019 for Power Users' course outline

events.id: Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour-Wellington Botanic Garden, 101 Glenmore St, Kelburn, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour
events.venue: Wellington Botanic Garden, 101 Glenmore St, Kelburn, Wellington
events.long_description:
Gather your friends, whānau, or neighbours who might find it tricky to access the gardens, and enjoy a relaxing, self-guided drive through a spectacular spring floral display at Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.

Simply drive along the one-way route past the Display Garden and soak in the colours of tulips, forget-me-nots, dianthus, primulas, chrysanthemums, daffodils, and more.

How it works:
- No registration needed — just turn up and enter through the Glenmore Street gates.
- Follow the designated one-way route through the gardens, keeping within your vehicle at all times.
- Exit through the West/White Gate to return to Glenmore Street.
- Feel free to enjoy the route as many times as you like during opening hours.

Please note:
- Drive slowly (maximum 10 km/h), and watch carefully for pedestrians, especially children.
- Stay in your vehicle for the entire tour to keep everyone safe and comfortable.
- Follow all signage and do not turn around within the garden grounds.

This event is self-guided and unstaffed. If you need assistance during your visit, please call 04 499 1400.
For enquiries, email treehouse@wcc.govt.nz or call 04 499 1400.

events.venue: Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
The satire we deserve: Brannavan Gnanalingam and Duncan Sarkies
Two novelists take the pulse of life in Aotearoa and diagnose a hilarious and dangerous arrhythmia. Brannavan Gnanalingam’s The Life and Opinions of Kartik Popat takes the gloves off to better prod the weeping sores of our body politic and social media. Duncan Sarkies depicts the farcical and chilling demise of democracy within an alpaca breeders’ association in Stargazers. Join Pip Adam as she asks both writers about the serious intent behind the hijinks and why it’s a good time to wield the satirical scalpel.

ADMISSION IS FREE—ALL WELCOME
Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre, Meow and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day and supported by the Letteri Family.

events.id: Draw It Out - Teens block course-level 2/105 High Street, Hutt Central, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Draw It Out - Teens block course
events.venue: level 2/105 High Street, Hutt Central, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
events.long_description:
A fun and deep way for teens (11-17 year olds) to learn to process their feelings.
Theme: Listening to your inner voice
Learn how to listen to your feelings and find guidance from within, using a gentle powerful tool called Interactive Drawing Therapy.
Teenage years can often be filled with external influences, making it hard to listen to our own inner voice for guidance. This 4-session block course teaches teens how to use drawing to process hard feelings and access their own inner resources, which can be used at home as visual journaling.
Dates
This block course consists of 4 workshops:
4.15pm-5.30pm
Tuesday 19th August - Metaphors for feelings
Tuesday 26th August - Uncovering needs
Tuesday 2nd September - Unlocking self-compassion
Monday 8th September - Curiosity in direction
Cost
$184 total ($46 per session)
Included in each session
You will be guided by Lara Phillips, a trained creative facilitator in Interactive Drawing Therapy, through drawing prompts (similar to a guided meditation or journaling) to draw out where you are at and draw out your own inner guidance. No art skills are needed, more simple mark making.
This gentle yet powerful tool uses drawing and writing as a way to access your subconscious and to listen to your heart rather than your head for guidance. A tool often used in therapy, it is made accessible for self-care and community wellness through these workshops.
About Lara Phillips
Lara Phillips is a creative facilitator trained in Interactive Drawing Therapy. With a 20 year career in creative copywriting in design and communication, she shares drawing and writing as a mode for wellness and self-care, to promote preventative and proactive mental health measures through creativity.
“We all have the wisdom within to help ourselves, if given the space.”
For more workshops or to book individual sessions visit www.drawitout.co.nz

Liability disclaimer
Draw It Out offers creativity for wellbeing. It is not intended as therapy nor does it replace counselling, therapy, or any other medical or clinical professional help. Participants are guided to draw out where they are at, whilst drawing out their own inner resources for support and guidance.
Participants understand it is their own responsibility to manage their mental and physical health during sessions, to opt in and out of activities as they see fit, and make the facilitator aware if further support is required.

events.id: Fundraiser For Trish's Campaign: Kneecap-59 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Fundraiser For Trish's Campaign: Kneecap
events.venue: 59 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
This time last year, Kneecap premiered at the Wellington Film Festival - but not enough people got to see it. Some films deserve the big screen experience, so I’m bringing it back!
Come along for a movie night supporting a great cause while enjoying this epic film. Set in Belfast, this wild, witty, and politically charged story follows the rise of the real-life rap trio Kneecap, blending music, humour, and rebellion in a way only the Irish can.
Your ticket includes the screening plus a raffle with a twist
- and every dollar goes towards my campaign - it will help me get to the finish line and helping to cover those last few expenses. Imagine the good we can do for our communities if I’m elected!
Date: Monday 8 September
Time: 5.45pm
Location: Lighthouse Cinema Cuba Street
It’s a perfect chance to laugh and cry - imagine Derry Girls, Trainspotting and Spinal Tap combined - it will change you for the better and help make a difference – so gather your mates and join us for some great craic!

events.name: Father's Day Quiz
events.venue: 1 Monorgan Road, Strathmore Park, Wellington 6022, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Put your general knowledge to the test while supporting a great cause at the Father's Day Quiz!
Join us for a belated celebration of the fathers and father figures in our lives. We welcome everyone to join us, including students and mothers, so make sure to get everyone a ticket.
Date: Monday 8 September
Time: 6:30pm-9pm
Cost: $25 per person, which includes a pizza dinner and a drink
Please bring gold coins for some exciting games to be played throughout the evening.
This event is part of the 2025 Middle School Challenge fundraiser for Blind Low Vision NZ. Our Middle School Leaders have the unique opportunity to sponsor the development and training of a Guide Dog named Cooper, which costs about $25,000. Your generous donations are greatly appreciated and make a significant difference. Once Cooper is fully trained, he will be placed with a visually impaired person for the rest of his working life. We believe that as the Scots Community bands together, your support can change a life.
To learn more or to make a donation, visit our Givealittle page.

events.id: Leadership And Management Part 1-AREA Meetings and Events, 1 O'Reily Ave, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Leadership And Management Part 1
events.venue: AREA Meetings and Events, 1 O'Reily Ave, Wellington
events.description:
Learn how to make the transition from buddy to the boss and lead a successful team.
Managing staff can be a very rewarding, interesting and fun role, it can also be a tough and demanding job.
Between managing your own time and projects, helping your team members solve problems and complete tasks, and helping other managers, your day can fill up before you know it.
This workshop aims to maximise your leadership and management potential and help you become a more confident, effective and efficient leader and manager with information on understanding personality types, effective communication, setting expectations and goals, assigning work, effective delegation, motivating staff, leadership styles, giving feedback and having courageous conversations, understanding what is required to be a good leader and manager and encouraging teamwork.
The workshop is designed for those who have been promoted recently into a supervisory management role or for those who have been there for some time but need to improve their leadership and management skills.

events.id: Customer Service Essentials-Level 13 157 Lambton Quay Wellington, 6011-Event Brite
events.name: Customer Service Essentials
events.venue: Level 13 157 Lambton Quay Wellington, 6011
events.long_description:
This course will cover the importance of creating a customer service mindset when dealing with your most important asset in a business, your customers. It introduces the key requirement to have a strong product knowledge, effective communication and listening skills, and polished customer service etiquette.

Key audience:
This course is suitable for employees who interact with customers on a regular basis, whether by phone or in person, and people who would like to gain a strong, foundational level of knowledge about how to deal effectively with customers.

Learning outcomes:
Understand the importance of a customer service mindset.
Learn about customer service etiquette and how it’s unique for each business.
Explain the requirement for a strong product and service knowledge.
Demonstrate the pivotal role of good communication and listening skills.

If you would like to register with Business Central directly and receive an invoice for payment, please contact our training team via training@businesscentral.org.nz.

Course Detail
Duration: Half day, in person
Time: 9am - 1pm

Course includes:
Workbook, arrival tea or coffee and morning or afternoon tea.
To view our Terms and Conditions click here.

events.name: Safeguarding week @ the Y
events.venue: Te Tai Ohinga Youth Hub, 203 Willis Street , Wellington
events.long_description:
Join us to mark Child Safeguarding week!!!!

Every child deserves to be safe, and the Y strives to create strong, safe practice within our organisation. Today we are celebrating the importance of Safeguarding, and this year's theme of " Parenting in a digital world".
Kathryn Berkett, NZ renowned educational psychologist, will join us to speak about the effects of devices on the brain. We will release the newest version of " the Y way", our safeguarding expectations for Y staff working with children and young people, and will have the first viewing of our new, child friendly safeguarding video.

This is a great opportunity for those that work, live and interact with children and young people.

For more information email: safeguarding@ycentral.nz

events.id: Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Whakatū Nelson-208 Bridge Street Nelson, Nelson Region 7010-Event Brite
events.name: Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Whakatū Nelson
events.venue: 208 Bridge Street Nelson, Nelson Region 7010
events.long_description:
Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene.
Timing:
Doors open: 5.00pm
Lecture: 5.30pm - 6.30pm
Q&A: 6.30pm - 7.00pm
Lecture dates:
Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington | Wednesday 3 September | Michael Fowler Centre
Tāhuna Queenstown | Friday 5 September | Crowne Plaza
Whakatū Nelson | Tuesday 9 September | The Suter - Te Aratoi o Whakatū
Ōtautahi Christchurch | Wednesday 10 September | Black Box Theatre - Papa Hou
Heretaunga Hastings | Thursday 11 September | Toi Toi
Ngāmotu New Plymouth | Monday 15 September | Novotel
Kirikiriroa Hamilton | Tuesday 16 September | Bill Gallagher Centre
Tāmaki Makaurua Auckland | Thursday 18 September | TBC

events.long_description:
Turn wine into watercolour! Take a brush in one hand, a drink in the other, and let’s paint a watercolour masterpiece!

Join us for a beginner's watercolour painting event full of fluid colour mixing and delicate brushwork where you’ll craft your own bespoke watercolour artwork. One of our watercolour experts will guide step-by-step through the watercolour process and will encourage you to add your own unique touch.

Drinks: No drinks are included in the ticket price, but drinks are available for purchase.

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality watercolour paper, watercolour paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). All our events are in licensed venues, so you can purchase drinks to sip as you create! At the end of the night, you will leave with your own watercolour painting!

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website.

events.id: Secure Development Training - September 2025-level 7/117 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Secure Development Training - September 2025
events.venue: level 7/117 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Have you been to a Kawaiicon and found yourself realising that you want to know more? Are you a curious developer who wants to know what happens if you prod a web application? Are you a QA looking to take the worst path possible through an app?
Maybe the PrivSec Secure Development Training is for you!
Agenda
The training is a one day course consisting of the following:
A detailed overview of the OWASP Top Ten Web Application vulnerabilities.
Multiple real world examples and case studies of exploited vulnerabilities.
Hands on experience exploiting these vulnerabilities on a custom web application
Techniques and tooling to identify and exploit these bug classes, using both source code analysis and dynamic testing techniques.
Remediation steps and techniques to mitigate and avoid these issues.
Outcomes
By the end of the day, you will have an understanding of tools and techniques used to compromise web applications and hands on experience in exploiting multiple vulnerabilities in the OWASP top ten.
About the Trainer
Training will be led by one of our Senior consultants, Jack Moran and supported by Sriram Jayaraman
Jack is a Senior Consultant at PrivSec Consulting. He has worked in the offensive security space for the better part of a decade, focusing on web and mobile application testing, along with code reviews and security configuration reviews. He has a number of CVEs credited to himself, and his enthusiasm towards security security is infectious.
Sriram is an ex-developer, turned security consultant. He has a strong background in web application penetration testing, along with code review. He has familiarity with several programming and scripting languages and frameworks such as Python, Javascript, PHP, Node.js, Angular and React.
Notes for the Day
Lunch and snacks will be provided. We will teach you how to hack.

Hands on experience exploiting these vulnerabilities on a custom web application Techniques and tooling to identify and exploit these bug classes, using both source code analysis and dynamic testing techniques.

events.id: Compliance made SME-asy: Employment basics with ATH Consulting-Holloway Street, Carterton 5713, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Compliance made SME-asy: Employment basics with ATH Consulting
events.venue: Holloway Street, Carterton 5713, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Are you confident in navigating the complexities of employment relationships in today’s ever-changing workplace? Join us for a comprehensive workshop designed for managers, employers, and business owners who want to deepen their understanding of employment fundamentals and people management best practices.
What You’ll Learn:
Foundations of Employment Relationships:
Explore the essential components that shape every employment relationship, including relevant legislation, terms and conditions, and the pivotal role of workplace policies and procedures.
Understanding Employment Types:
Distinguish between permanent, full-time, casual, and seasonal roles, and learn how each type impacts your obligations and management strategies.
Employment Legislation Essentials:
Get a practical overview of the 10 key employment laws that influence your workplace, ensuring you stay compliant and informed.
Good Faith and Agreements:
Discover the importance of acting in good faith and the differences between Individual Employment Agreements (IEA) and Collective Employment Agreements (CEA), including mandatory clauses and recommended “nice to have” terms.
Managing Change:
Learn best practices for handling variations to employment agreements and implementing effective workplace policies and procedures.
People Management Mastery:
Gain insights into the employee lifecycle, building a strong employment brand, and managing common workplace issues such as performance improvement plans (PiP), disciplinary processes, attendance, and health and wellbeing.
Leadership and Succession:
Identify the hallmarks of poor leadership and develop strategies for effective succession planning to future-proof your team.
Support Systems:
Know where to get help—learn when to trust your gut, when to rely on facts, and how to access the right support at the right time.
This workshop is your opportunity to build confidence, reduce risk, and enhance your leadership toolkit. Whether you’re new to managing people or looking to refresh your knowledge, you’ll leave with practical insights and actionable strategies for every stage of the employment relationship.
Don’t miss this chance to strengthen your employment management skills and connect with peers facing similar challenges. Register now and take the next step toward becoming a more effective, knowledgeable, and resilient leader.
When: Wednesday 10 September 9.00 am - 11.00 am
Where: Carterton Community Courthouse (next to Events Centre) Holloway Street, Carterton
Cost: Members $65 + GST, Non-Members $120 +GST
This workshop needs a minimum of 15 attendees to go ahead.

events.id: There Once Was a Boy...-BATS Theatre, 1 Kent Tce, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: There Once Was a Boy...
events.venue: BATS Theatre, 1 Kent Tce, Wellington
events.long_description:
Written and performed by Robert Lloyd

A boy is stranded at sea. A storm bears down on him, and, in what he believes are his final moments, he ponders his life and the choice he made to come here—to explore what’s over the curious horizon—and wonders: Was this a mistake? There once was a boy… is a fun, poetic performance for tweens, teens and their whānau. This live “pop-up book” explores curiosity, courage, and finding light in the darkness.

Recommended for audiences aged 10+. Contains flashing lights.

This show was created as part of the TAHI Festival 2025 Creative Residency programme, in partnership with Creative NZ, PAYPA and Toi Poneke Arts Centre.

events.name: Café Scientifique - Space: What Is Our Place In the Cosmos?
events.venue: Southern Cross Garden Bar Restaurant, 39 Abel Smith St, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
Join us for a new Café Scientifique series hosted by Pūtaiao ki te Pāpori—School of Science in Society.

At this first event in September, astrophysicist Dr Yvette Perrott and novelist Dr Tim Corballis will discuss the evolving picture physics gives us about the nature of the universe, and the ways people find their place in it.

Café Scientifique is a place where, for the price of a cup of coffee or a glass of wine, anyone can come to explore the latest ideas in science and technology in a relaxed, friendly environment.

The evening will start with a short introduction from the speakers, followed by a question-and-answer conversation.

Doors open at 5.30 pm, talks begin at 6 pm. All welcome—free entry, nibbles provided.

Please note: anyone under the age of 18 must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
For further information, please contact scienceinsociety@vuw.ac.nz.

events.id: Wellington Mayoral Debate 2025-Rutherford House Victoria University of Wellington Wellington, 6011-Event Brite
events.name: Wellington Mayoral Debate 2025
events.venue: Rutherford House Victoria University of Wellington Wellington, 6011
events.long_description:
There is no denying that public sentiment in Wellington has taken a beating. Dwindling economic stats, a struggling CBD and major infrastructure challenges have left the Wellington community feeling unhappy and unheard – and nobody has felt this more than the businesses in that community.
Every electoral cycle has debates, and all of them have politics. But this is the debate to attend if you are in business in Wellington, because unlike the others this debate is focused directly on what matters most to you.
What’s in-store
In partnership with The Post, BNZ & Victoria University of Wellington - Te Herenga Waka, the Wellington Chamber of Commerce is delivering the premier local government event for Wellington business: the 2025 Wellington Mayoral Debate.
Hear candidates Andrew Little, Ray Chung, Diane Calvert, Karl Tiefenbacher and Alex Baker talk about their vision for economic growth, their policy plans to stimulate business and their views on how council can work better with the private sector, all moderated by The Post’s own Andrea Vance.
Following the debate there will be the chance for open questions from the audience, providing you with the chance to hold candidates to account on the issues that matter most to you.
Light refreshments will be provided after the debate, where you’ll be able to network with candidates and business leaders.
Agenda:
5.30pm - Debate
6.30pm - Audience Q&A
7.00pm - Networking with drinks & nibbles
7.30pm - Event ends
Thank you to our media partner The Post , our venue partner, Victoria University of Wellington - Te Herenga Waka, and our supporting partner BNZ for their support.

events.id: Chloe's Revenge-1 Kent Ter, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Chloe's Revenge
events.venue: 1 Kent Ter, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Written and performed by Chloe Bettina.
Part love letter, part exposé, Chloe’s Revenge is a musical theatre-inspired show that pulls back the curtain on the pro-am musical theatre “industry” in Aotearoa. With biting wit, Chloe lays bare the heartbreak of rejection from the world she adores, and turns that pain into power. This is a story of survival, self-discovery, and the ultimate comeback: becoming the best version of yourself when the system says you don’t belong. You don't have to be a "musical theatre person" to enjoy this show. In fact, it's better if you're not.

events.id: Pacific Peoples and the Underclass of Aotearoa New Zealand: Repositioning the Narrative-11 Turnbull Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Pacific Peoples and the Underclass of Aotearoa New Zealand: Repositioning the Narrative
events.venue: 11 Turnbull Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
In 2018, over 380,000 people in Aotearoa New Zealand identified with at least one Pacific ethnicity. Despite being a youthful and growing community, Pacific peoples are statistically entrenched in a cycle of disadvantage that cannot be ignored.
In almost every measure—health, education, income, home ownership, and justice—Pacific people are overrepresented in poor outcomes.
We are not just facing a Pacific problem; we are looking at the face of New Zealand’s underclass—systemic, intergenerational, and largely invisible in mainstream policy conversations. Despite progress for some groups, the Pacific population remains on the wrong side of the statistical ledger.
Pacific peoples experience:
• The highest rates of avoidable hospitalisations and chronic conditions.
• Worst material deprivation across nearly every indicator.
• Persistently low home ownership rates.
• A widening education achievement gap, often masked by ethnic averages.
• Underrepresentation in decision-making, leadership, and governance roles.
While initiatives for Māori advancement are critical and must continue, Pacific peoples require their own distinct policy lens. A “one-size-fits-all” approach under a pan-ethnic umbrella risks making the Pacific experience invisible.

events.id: ROADKILL: The Uber-cool Musical - TAHI Festival: CANCELLED-Hannah Playhouse, 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: ROADKILL: The Uber-cool Musical - TAHI Festival: CANCELLED
events.venue: Hannah Playhouse, 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
Hey everyone- we have a little change of plans!
Unfortunately, ROADKILL: The Uber-Cool Musical won’t be happening this time around, but we’re already cooking up something even better for the future. All ticket holders will receive a full refund and we can’t wait to welcome you to our next big adventure.
Thank you for your excitement and your support.

CANCELLED-


ROADKILL The Uber-Cool Musical takes you on a wildly immersive journey through love, life and rock ’n’ roll — all from the back seat of a van. This intimate one-man musical combines humour, heart and unforgettable tunes for an experience like no other.
Strap in for the rollercoaster ride of your life as we take a regular mundane occurrence of driving in an Uber and blow wide open the private life, memories and miss happenings of our hero, and driver, Terry.

Carpool karaoke meets intense love story meets wild murder mystery.

Much more than a musical, its an experience, its a journey and an attraction!

In the space of a usual cabaret show and with the help of the passengers in the van, you will witness and be part of, childhood dreams, births, deaths and marriages, high drama, dark comedy, all sung live with a kickass, original, meatloaf-esque rock soundtrack. Surprises and magic ensues as we push the van, and Terry, to the limits of what is possible.

This will be an intimate, sensory overload, in a van. A full grand musical with all the bells and whistles.

With only 9 seats available each ride, grab your mates and have a private experience in the fast lane!
The hottest ticket in town- be sure to experience the ride of your life!

The show is in the style of a musical crossed with karaoke songs you have never heard before...

The van will be stationary and parked for this initial season.

Winner of BEST IN FRINGE and EMERGING ARTIST OF THE YEAR at the Dunedin Fringe and Winner of MOST INNOVATIVE at the NZ Fringe awards this year!

events.long_description:
This spring from the 28th of August to the 2nd of October we will be screening a series of excellent Palestinian films, old and new, every week at two/fiftyseven on Willis Street, with ticket sales going to the Gazan mutual aid group The Sameer Project.
The Sameer Project is an on-the-ground aid organisation organised by Palestinians in the diaspora, which crowdfunds in order to provide tents, medical care and direct cash aid to those most affected in Gaza. They can be found on Instagram at @thesameerproject.
More information about The Wanted 18, screening on the 10th of September can be found at https://www.palestinefilminstitute.org/en/pfp/archive/wanted-18.

Grass Roots is a heartfelt and charming musical about the colossal culture of rugby. From club fields to Eden Park, a queer boy embarks on an epic odyssey through the New Zealand Rugby ages. Join him in this historical exploration of takatāpuitanga, masculinity, fatherhood, and what it means to grow up in Aotearoa. Created for rangatahi and whānau, this powerful story speaks to all generations.

events.id: Empowering Aotearoa New Zealand’s Digital Future-Level 2/40 Bowen Street, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Empowering Aotearoa New Zealand’s Digital Future
events.venue: Level 2/40 Bowen Street, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
You’re invited to the launch of NZTech’s latest landmark report: Empowering Aotearoa New Zealand’s Digital Future – Our National Data Centre Infrastructure.
Data centres are the backbone of our digital lives, powering everything from essential government services and healthcare to banking, e-commerce, and artificial intelligence (AI).  As data centre demand rises, so does the need for a resilient and sustainable energy supply. This sector is playing a pivotal role in New Zealand’s transition to a low-carbon future and helping to future-proof the electricity grid.
Discover what’s really happening with New Zealand’s booming data centre sector and what it means for our economy, communities and our digital future. Meet the data centre operators and electricity providers driving this transformation, and hear directly from Hon Simon Watts, Minister for Energy and Climate Change, and Graeme Muller, CEO, NZTech.
 Join us and find out:
how data centres power our everyday lives and the scale of New Zealand’s data centre sector
how the sector is fuelling economic growth and generating thousands of jobs
why New Zealand’s data centres are global leaders in energy efficiency and driving investment in new wind, solar and geothermal projects
how New Zealand is uniquely positioned to become a regional hub for sustainable digital exports.
the importance of collaboration between government and industry to ensure renewable energy supply can keep pace with digital growth. 
Learn more about how the digital economy and energy sector are working together to unlock new value for all New Zealanders, ensuring our country thrives in a rapidly evolving digital world.

events.id: The Liberal International Order as a Core-Periphery Order: An Alternative History with Multiple Deep Contestations-room 101/16 Kelburn Parade, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: The Liberal International Order as a Core-Periphery Order: An Alternative History with Multiple Deep Contestations
events.venue: room 101/16 Kelburn Parade, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.long_description:
I offer an alternative macrohistory of the Liberal International Order (LIO) that was explicitly designed to perpetuate Western dominance and American hegemony. The LIO is better understood as a core-periphery order because inequality between the Western-core and the ‘Restern’-periphery was constitutive of it. (Re-)Imperialism—not just liberalism—remained a central ordering mechanism well after 1945. I show the two-way deep contestations between the liberal and anticolonial ordering projects, especially at the 1955 Bandung Conference. Contra the post-LIO pessimism of disorder/chaos, I argue that the normative agency of the Southeast Asian states informed by the legacy of Bandung is heralding a multiplex, multi-regional world order. As the declining inequality between the West and Asia transforms the core-periphery LIO, the emergent decentered world order will lack a core, whether Western/liberal or Asian. This deep transformation should be welcomed, not deeply contested, although coexistence and global integration require embracing deep pluralism, not liberalism.
Manjeet S. Pardesi is Associate Professor of International Relations in the Political Science and International Relations Programme, and Asia Research Fellow at the Centre for Strategic Studies at Victoria University of Wellington. His research interests include World Orders and World/Global History, Great Power Politics, Asian security, and the Sino-Indian rivalry. His most recent book, Divergent Worlds: What the Ancient Mediterranean and Indian Ocean Can Tell Us About the Future of International Order (co-authored with Amitav Acharya) was published by Yale University Press in 2025.
events.description:
I offer an alternative macrohistory of the Liberal International Order (LIO) that was explicitly designed to perpetuate Western dominance and American hegemony.
The LIO is better understood as a core-periphery order because inequality between the Western-core and the ‘Restern’-periphery was constitutive of it.
(Re-)Imperialism—not just liberalism—remained a central ordering mechanism well after 1945.
I show the two-way deep contestations between the liberal and anticolonial ordering projects, especially at the 1955 Bandung Conference.
Contra the post-LIO pessimism of disorder/chaos, I argue that the normative agency of the Southeast Asian states informed by the legacy of Bandung is heralding a multiplex, multi-regional world order.

events.id: After 5: Wellington Free Ambulance-Level 13, 157 Lambton Quay Wellington, Wellington Region 6011-Event Brite
events.name: After 5: Wellington Free Ambulance
events.venue: Level 13, 157 Lambton Quay Wellington, Wellington Region 6011
events.long_description:
Most sudden cardiac arrests happen at home in the community, would you know how to instantly help a family member or neighbour?
Go beyond regular networking and learn vital skills in this special session with Wellington Free Ambulance. You’ll learn about our region’s uniquely free emergency ambulance service, their incredible heritage story, and connection to the community that continues today.
You’ll be able to learn CPR – a vital and potentially lifesaving skill that will give you the confidence and skills to help your community when it matters most. You’ll also get to see how an AED works!
Most importantly, this event will showcase the range of ways you or your business can keep the FREE in Wellington Free Ambulance. Your support is vital to ensure ambulance services stay free of charge in our community, so make sure you secure your spot at this potentially life-saving evening.
Click here to secure your spot.

events.id: Glass Jewellery-making - 4-week Block-Workspace Ōtaki, 6 Hewson Crescent, Ōtaki-Event Finder
events.name: Glass Jewellery-making - 4-week Block
events.venue: Workspace Ōtaki, 6 Hewson Crescent, Ōtaki
events.long_description:
Join us for this fabulous block of classes in glass jewellery-making! The course starts on Thursday 11 September and runs for 4 weeks until Thursday 2 October, 5.30pm - 8.30pm.

This course is a great way for beginners and those with some experience to get into working with glass to produce beautiful beads that can be used in a myriad of ways.

Students will learn correct tool use and gain a solid understanding of the lampwork process. They will also learn some ways of incorporating their beads into wearable jewellery with silver and/or stainless-steel findings

Course cost includes set materials, such as glass and stainless-steel findings. Silver, findings and extra glass are available to purchase in the studio.

People under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

events.name: Paint and Wine Night in Waikanae Beach - Mothers Tulips
events.venue: Hey Coastie, Wellington, 42 Tutere Street, Waikanae
events.long_description:
The concept is simple - take a brush in one hand, a drink in the other and let’s paint a masterpiece!

Join us for a creative night of drinking and painting in the heart of Waikanae! No previous painting experience necessary. Get your creative juices flowing and your brush strokes going!

Drinks: FIRST DRINK IS INCLUDED IN THE TICKET PRICE

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website.

events.id: Wellington Law Revue 2025 - Much Ado About Money (and Cycle Lanes)-Student Union Building, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Wellington Law Revue 2025 - Much Ado About Money (and Cycle Lanes)
events.venue: Student Union Building, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.long_description:
With the local elections looming, the Wellington City Council is divided. The National-led government wants to intervene, appointing none other than the Monopoly Man (yes the one from the board game!) to the job of fixing the Council. What they didn’t see coming is that this money-grabbing billionaire has his own personal agenda: money, money, money. 
Meanwhile, four flatmates are stunned to find a new Mega Cycle Lane has been built through their front garden. Trying to get to the bottom of this, the flatmates unravel a sinister conspiracy that leads back to one man...
The Monopoly Man!
Can our heroes bankrupt our villain on the Monopoly board and beat him at his own game? Find out at the 2025 production of the Wellington Law Revue: Much Ado About Money (and Cycle Lanes).

events.id: Kevin Bloody Wilson Aussie Icon Tour-The Opera House, 111 - 113 Manners Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Kevin Bloody Wilson Aussie Icon Tour
events.venue: The Opera House, 111 - 113 Manners Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
The much-loved and outrageously funny comedian KEVIN BLOODY WILSON is coming back to NZ in August & September with his new “Aussie Icon Tour”, performing again his funniest songs, hilarious stories and shooting down political correctness for his Kiwi fans supported by Jenny Talia from Australia. He’s fair-dinkum funny helping to prevent global boring!
With 350 million TikTok views, 4 million album sales and 6 million tickets sold around the world, Kevin Bloody Wilson shows no signs of slowing down because he says “there is just too much political correctness to incorrect!”
“I love being on stage when every bugger in the audience knows every word to my songs. I now call them my DILLIGAF CHOIR and I don’t think there is a bigger choir in the world than the Kevin Bloody Wilson DILLIGAF CHOIR!” says Kevin.
Since releasing his first hugely popular album “Your Average Australian Yobbo” in 1984 and hit songs like “Hey Santa Claus”, Kevin Bloody Wilson has become a global comedy institution with an extensive multi-generational fan base stretching from the Australian Outback to Buckingham Palace, and that most definitely includes New Zealand. Even Billy Connolly calls him ‘the world’s funniest Australian’. Kev’s irreverent R18 humour may not be to everyone’s taste, but it certainly has been enjoyed by a heck of a lot of Kiwi’s who have laughed and sung along with him on his many tours here since the 1990’s; sharing the ditties that first sparked imaginations with their children and now their grandchildren. His loyal fans should not miss this further opportunity to enjoy another big dose of Kev and for those not yet acquainted you’re invited to enjoy a knee-slapping, hilarious night out.
R18 restriction applies.
Tickets from $66.50 plus booking fees

events.id: Shaun Kirk - New Zealand Tour 2025-Vogelmorn Upstairs, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Shaun Kirk - New Zealand Tour 2025
events.venue: Vogelmorn Upstairs, Wellington
events.description:
Hailing from the music-filled streets of Melbourne, Australia, Shaun Kirk is an award-winning blues and soul troubadour recognized for his exceptional talent as a born entertainer.
His unique talent has not only earned him many accolades but also much praise from fellow artists, such as three-time Grammy Award Winner Fantastic Negrito, who has declared his show as One of the best one-man shows he’s ever seen!
Kirk's vocals exude a gritty, soulful depth that seems to transcend far beyond his years, with critics continually acclaiming him as one of the finest blues voices Australia has ever heard (Buzz Mag).
Complementing his vocal artistry, Kirk's vintage guitar tones and raw grooves pay tribute to the timeless influences that have shaped his musical journey, resulting in a distinctive sound fast becoming his own.
Shaun’s musical journey has taken him to stages all over the world, where he's not only performed but consistently sold out shows, leaving audiences enthralled by his magnetic presence.

events.description:
Mallrat Brings “Light Hit My Face Like A Straight Right” Tour To New Zealand Australian indie pop princess Mallrat will return to New Zealand this September on the Light Hit My Face Like a Straight Right World Tour, following a run of sold out shows across Europe and USA.
Sophomore album Light Hit My Face Like A Straight brings dance music that has heart and potent magic which will be manifested into life on stage, alongside all your favourite Mallrat hits and accompanied by her incredible live band.
The adored songwriter and producer’s work catapulted Mallrat across the globe with critical acclaim from NPR, Stereogum, NME, NYLON, PAPER Magazine, The New York Times, Billboard, Noisey and more, further affirming Mallrat as a beacon primed for the world stage in 2025.
Joining Mallrat on her New Zealand headline shows is none other than Aotearoa’s own indie pop darling, Riiki Reid — bringing her signature style and infectious energy to the stage for an unforgettable night of music.

events.name: Maracatui
events.venue: The Rogue & Vagabond
events.long_description:
Get ready for a night of pulsating Brazilian rhythms as Maracatui ignites the stage at Rogue and
Vagabond.

Rooted in the rich cultural traditions of northeast Brazil, this vibrant collective of musicians and vocalists honours the powerful percussion and soulful songs created by past generations. Maracatui has evolved over the years, blending traditional sounds with original compositions and modern production techniques to create a sound that's both authentic and new.

Known for their infectious energy, Maracatui's performances are an irresistible invitation for audience participation. Their unique blend of powerful beats and beautiful melodies creates a communal experience that will leave you feeling uplifted.

And to be honest, the beer is also stellar! We love Rogue!

Music from 9:30

events.name: Wellington Spring Festival – Government House Garden tour
events.venue: Government House Visitor Centre, Hospital Road Entrance, Newtown Wellington, Wellington
events.long_description:
As part of Wellington's Spring Fetival, explore Government House gardens with the BARK garden team (90 minute tour)

Government House was opened in Newtown in 1910, and its extensive gardens have been in continuous development since then. As part of the Spring Festival, the Government House garden team is offering guided walks through our gardens. Tours will go ahead regardless of weather. Tours will not enter the main house.

Bookings are essential for the free tour. Places are limited: https://gg.govt.nz/government-house/government-house-wellington/government-house-tours/upcoming

Some parts of our grounds are not mobility friendly. Please contact the Visitor Centre direct if you have any questions regarding accessibility.

Groups wanting to organise a garden tour or house tour can email our Visitor Centre team direct: bookings@govthouse.govt.nz

If you have any questions or need more information, please email us at bookings@govthouse.govt.nz, or call us at 04-382-0837. You will receive a reminder email 24 hours before your tour.

events.id: Leadlight Glass - 4 Weeks Block-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Leadlight Glass - 4 Weeks Block
events.venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
events.long_description:
Learn to create gorgeous leadlight designs with our experienced jewellers! This great course runs from Friday 12 September for 4 weeks until Friday 3 October, 5.30pm - 8pm.

Your 4-week block will give you time to learn the basics and then create one or more leadlight projects.

This class is ideal for creating sun-catchers or small decorative projects for beginners, or working on slightly more complex pieces for those with some experience.

Beginners will start by planning their design, then learning to cut the glass, and prepare it before foiling and soldering each piece, creating a simple elegant clear glass starter project.

Beautiful coloured glass, copper foil and leadlight solder are then available to purchase as required for your other projects.

This is a warm and friendly class with excellent support and learning for complete beginners and more advanced students. All tools are supplied, though you are welcome to bring your own tools and glass if you have them.

Your materials for your beginner project are supplied as part of your course fee, extra materials will be available for purchase if you wish to make larger pieces or more than one project.

events.id: Sika Sound Journey-Thistle Hall, 293 Cuba St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Sika Sound Journey
events.venue: Thistle Hall, 293 Cuba St, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
This powerful experience is like a soundtrack that is crafted to go with your life.

Something between an ancient ceremony and a movie soundtrack.

Please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket. Be prepared to drop into a deep space.
Door sales will be available if there is space. Advanced booking is recommended.

Sika's Sound Journeys are truly unique. They are sonic explorations that feature didgeridoos, drums, flutes, voice and orchestral elements. A collection of foraged sounds from objects he has recorded in nature, add even more textures. Many of his sounds are completely unrecognisable and abstract. Immersed in this cocoon of abstract sound, we can find ourselves in the most surprising places in our mind. In this timeless realm, beyond the normal limitations of rational reality, anything is possible.

An epic adventure deep inside yourself.

Journey to worlds within worlds on incredible sound waves.

Sika creates a safe space to relax deeply and connect with our inner guidance. This Sound Journey begins and ends with a short guided visualisation.

There will be two journeys with an interval. Most people choose to lie down, so once again, please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket to get really comfortable.

A journal is also recommended.

events.id: The Monster in the Maze-St James Theatre, 77-87 Courtenay Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: The Monster in the Maze
events.venue: St James Theatre, 77-87 Courtenay Place, Wellington
events.long_description:
The myth of the Minotaur is a tale almost as old as storytelling itself, but with The Monster in the Maze Jonathan Dove and Alisdair Middleton have excavated rich, new life from this classic. In this brand new staging by director Anapela Polataivao (Red White and Brass, Wild Dogs Under My Skirt), this story will be told as never before.

When King Minos defeats the Athenians, he metes out his punishment in the cruellest way possible: by destroying their hope for the future. Every year, the king compels the conquered Athenians to send him their youth, to be fed to the terrible beast at the centre of his island’s maze: the Minotaur. As King Minos triumphs, his great monster “will eat your future, it will rip your hope, it will stamp your youth, your children in the sand.”

As the vindictive king will soon learn, however, these youth will not accept their fate without a fierce challenge. The Monster in the Maze is a story about resistance; about justice; about finding power not in oppression, but in collectivism. Fittingly, then, it’s also a groundbreaking work in its form: a community-focused and community-driven opera in which young and community singers and players stand proudly shoulder-to-shoulder with their professional counterparts, and in which both are integral.

The Monster in the Maze has been roundly praised by audiences, participants and reviewers worldwide, and in its Aotearoa debut season, it will serve as a gorgeous articulation of New Zealand Opera’s reciprocal community kaupapa.

Sung in English with surtitles.
events.description:
The myth of the Minotaur is a tale almost as old as storytelling itself, but with The Monster in the Maze Jonathan Dove and Alisdair Middleton have excavated rich, new life from this classic.
In this brand new staging by director Anapela Polataivao (Red White and Brass, Wild Dogs Under My Skirt), this story will be told as never before.
When King Minos defeats the Athenians, he metes out his punishment in the cruellest way possible: by destroying their hope for the future.
Every year, the king compels the conquered Athenians to send him their youth, to be fed to the terrible beast at the centre of his island’s maze: the Minotaur.
As King Minos triumphs, his great monster “will eat your future, it will rip your hope, it will stamp your youth, your children in the sand.” As the vindictive king will soon learn, however, these youth will not accept their fate without a fierce challenge.

events.long_description:
Do You Believe in Ghosts?
In a rapidly gentrifying part of London, a married couple are renovating their new home. But something strange and frightening can be heard at the same time every night. What forces have they disturbed? Jenny has become convinced the house is haunted. Husband Sam isn’t having a bar of it. Tension builds throughout a housewarming dinner with friends as the clock ticks closer to 2:22… when a shocking truth will be revealed.
“Sharp, quick, and cleverly layered with clues – a thunderous fright night.” - The Guardian
Spine-chillingly funny, scary and filled with suspense, Join us for the New Zealand premiere of Danny Robin's West-End smash hit, directed by stage and screen legend Peter Feeney. Starring the unparalleled talents of:
Regan Taylor
Pamela Sidhu
Jack Sergent-Shadbolt
Serena Cotton
With otherworldly design by Chris Reddington, Marcus McShane, Daniel Elliott and Shiloh Dobie, 2:22 A Ghost Story is set to be the most spook-tacular event of the year! BOOK NOW!

events.name: Shady Nasty, Debut Aotearoa Shows
events.venue: Valhalla, 154 Vivian Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
Following the release of their debut album TREK and a string of sold-out shows across Sydney (Eora), Brisbane (Meanjin), and Melbourne (Naarm), Sydney post-punk trio Shady Nasty announce their debut tour in Aotearoa/New Zealand this September.

A world bound by modding cars, immigrant heritage and digital obsessions, Kevin Stathis, Haydn Green and Luca Watson, together play a left-field breed of punk that recalibrates their formal training to its most uncustomary extremes.

Wherever they play and no matter the room size, devout adherents clammer to propel a heaving mosh. Experience TREK live as Shady Nasty debut the record with an all-new live show, with special guests to be announced.

events.long_description:
Tāmaki Makaurau post-punk outfit Soft Bait are hitting the road this September in celebration of their new album Life Advice, out July 25 via Flying Nun Records.

Known for their sharp lyricism, driving basslines and chaotic-but-considered live shows, the four-piece are bringing their wiry energy and weird charm to stages across the motu. Life Advice is a hook-heavy record full of tightly wound rhythms, jagged guitars and lines that sound like overheard wisdom from a mate you probably shouldn’t be listening to.

events.name: Take A Kid Tramping - Maketawa Hut Overnight
events.venue: Wellington
events.long_description:
Family tramping.
Take a Kid Tramping Trip for our kids with extra stamina and ability to carry an overnight pack, this one has a lot of climbing. We will head up the translator track from North Egmont, turn off and follow the ridge down to the hut. The next day we will return via the Makatawa track down through the bush and across a few streams.
All participants must be equipped for tramping in alpine conditions. Overnight tramping equipment required.
Children must be accompanied by a parent or caregiver approved by their guardian.
Shared transport costs apply, unless own transport is provided.
$10 per adult passenger, kids or own car free + hut fee.
Hut Tickets or annual pass required.
If interested, please register by Thursday 11 September:
Jo-anne Mowat | takt@nptc.org.nz

events.id: Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day-Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush, 160 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day
events.venue: Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush, 160 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington
events.long_description:
Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10:30 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10:30 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses. Free registration opens soon

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (weed-busting fun)

Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

events.id: What I Wish I Knew About Index Funds 5 Years Ago-Toi Pōneke Arts Centre, 61-69 Abel Smith St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: What I Wish I Knew About Index Funds 5 Years Ago
events.venue: Toi Pōneke Arts Centre, 61-69 Abel Smith St, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
People often ask me, “How do I best start investing?” It’s a great question—but not something I can explain in just a few minutes. That’s why I created this workshop.

This is a beginner-friendly, educational session focused on index fund investing—what it is, how it works, and how to actually get started. I’ll walk you through the full process: from understanding the basics to setting up your accounts, learning the key jargon, and knowing how to choose a fund that fits you.

We’ll cover important things like fees, tax, coverage, hedging, and more—things most people overlook when they first start. It’s not just theory. You’ll leave with a clear understanding of what to look for and how to take action confidently.

I’m not a financial adviser—this isn’t personal advice. It’s everything I wish someone had explained to me earlier. Because when you understand the process and use a simple strategy like dollar-cost averaging, you really can set yourself up for the long term.

If you’ve never invested before or just want to finally make sense of it all, this workshop is for you.
events.description:
People often ask me, “How do I best start investing?” It’s a great question—but not something I can explain in just a few minutes.
I’ll walk you through the full process: from understanding the basics to setting up your accounts, learning the key jargon, and knowing how to choose a fund that fits you.
We’ll cover important things like fees, tax, coverage, hedging, and more—things most people overlook when they first start.
I’m not a financial adviser—this isn’t personal advice.
If you’ve never invested before or just want to finally make sense of it all, this workshop is for you.

events.id: B.M.I : Bad Mōmona Individual (Playreading)-BATS Theatre, 1 Kent Tce, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: B.M.I : Bad Mōmona Individual (Playreading)
events.venue: BATS Theatre, 1 Kent Tce, Wellington
events.long_description:
Created by Īhaka Martyn. Play read by Kaisa Fa'atui

Tired of having no room for self love? Maybe burning 50kgs in 50 minutes will change that.

Join our inspiring fitness guru as he shows the audience how to shed your ego and excess fat. By utilising the power of manifestation, you too can change your pathetic little impulses. In fact, when was the last time you went to the gym? Maybe you should just skip this show and hit the treadmill instead, yeah?

Filled with self-helpless tips, banging tunes and kōrero hōhonu, this playreading will dissect the fraught relationships we have with our tinana, and where those nasty thoughts are really coming from.

Audience care: Contains body image themes and reference to “Fatphobia.”

events.venue: Te Aro Zero Waste @ Sustainability Trust, 2 Forresters Lane, CBD, Wellington
events.long_description:
Discover a more sustainable way to clean and care for your home!

Join eco-lifestylist Stella Carruthers for this hands-on workshop teaching you how to clean with no chemicals. Become aware of the dangers of greenwashing and how to identify commercial products that are safe for both people and planet.

Learn how to make your own effective cleaning solutions using simple ingredients from your kitchen. Discover that cleaning green not only saves you money, it can also support sustainable action that starts right in your home.

Please bring 2 small bottles and 1 container to take away samples of products. These can be upcycled items such as hummus pottles and small soda bottles for containers.

Spaces are limited, book now to clean green this spring!

A fabulous and fun workshop that combines creativity and gin tasting for a unique experience. Create one stunning large wall art piece or two smaller pieces that will be fired and glazed in either a striking emerald green or a vibrant blue around 5 weeks after the session, making it perfect for displaying in your home or as a thoughtful gift. Alongside that sip 3 delicious Gin samples from the Bond Store distillery where we will be working.

My clay classes are suitable for complete beginners or those with experience and are a wonderful way to relax, replenish and have fun. Working with clay is good for the soul! Price includes all materials, glaze, double kiln firing and a gin tasting tray with 3 gins from The Bond Store.

events.name: Homicidal Pacifist - Dust Off Your Guillotines
events.venue: Hannah Playhouse, 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
Created and performed by Sameena Zehra

This sold-out Pōneke favourite returns for one night only at Hannah Playhouse!

Three haunted sock puppets leading government. Shit-for-brains liberals peddling ‘both sides’ fucknuggetry as the people march for peace and their governments pour gasoline on fire. And WT actual F is a ‘lesser’ evil? Sameena Zehra is back to explore whether it's time to dust off your guillotines (even for a pacifist, it’s definitely time) with dark comedy and delicious storytelling that will make you gasp and guffaw as you channel your inner homicidal pacifist to pen a culling list of your own.

“As a piece of political theatre, this is one of the more entertaining and potentially moving with a flair for the dramatic... a remarkable raconteur with amazing stories to tell…” - Nicholas Holm, The Post

Audience care and considerations: This show is accessible to blind and low vision audiences without the need for audio description. The venue is fully accessible. Sameena may occasionally raise her voice, but won’t shout. There is some direct audience interaction, but if you avert your gaze or shake your head, you will not be engaged directly. Contains adult themes, political and confrontational material, and coarse language.

General admission - choose your price: $8 - $100

events.id: REMEMBRANCE- Somatic Dance-90 Hamilton Road, Hataitai, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: REMEMBRANCE- Somatic Dance
events.venue: 90 Hamilton Road, Hataitai, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.long_description:
REMEMBRANCE
A somatic dance journey
Join embodiment facilitators Jenna Joan & Sonic Sutra for an evening of connection, ceremonial cacao, freeform movement, and live soundscape.
🌑 Saturday 13 September
🕕 6–8.30pm
📍 All Saints Church Hall, Hataitai
🎟️ $40–$50
✨ Sober · Non-judgemental · All welcome · No experience needed
No door sales - tickets must be purchased online prior to the event.
As the season turns to spring, we gather in remembrance—an invitation to embody the strength within and feel how ancestral wisdom moves through us. When we connect to our inner foundations, we touch the support of those who came before and deepen our sense of belonging to life itself.
We’ll begin with ceremonial cacao, then drop into a guided movement journey with live soundscape. There are no steps to learn, no performance—just presence, curiosity, and letting your body move as it feels. Barefoot and phone-free, you’re invited to drop deep into free-form movement, awakening parts of you that you may have forgotten.
Come as you are.
Move with what you feel.
Leave feeling empowered, connected, and alive.
Somatic dance is a guided movement practice that helps you tune into your body’s wisdom and move from the inside out. Unlike ecstatic dance, which is typically an open, DJ-led space with no facilitation, somatic dance offers gentle guidance to support you in exploring sensation, emotion, and embodiment in a safe, intentional way. You’re not learning steps or performing—you're being invited into presence, curiosity, and feeling. With a focus on nervous system regulation, personal expression, and inner listening, somatic dance creates a nurturing space to come home to yourself.
Your Hosts...
Jenna Joan | Embodiment Facilitator
Jenna Joan is a somatic therapist, yoga teacher, and group facilitator who has been leading movement spaces for over 15 years. With a background in yoga, somatic dance, and therapeutic embodiment, her work blends play, authenticity, and deep nervous system awareness. Jenna is also a cacao alchemist and ceremonial facilitator, known for creating safe, soulful spaces that invite freedom, connection, and inner exploration. She has been hosting workshops, retreats, and community events for nearly a decade, and also works 1:1 in more therapeutic settings.
Sonic Sutra | Somatic Dance DJ
Sonic Sutra is a sound artist and somatic dance DJ who creates immersive musical journeys designed to support authentic movement, emotional release, and deep embodiment. With a focus on somatic dance and therapeutic soundscapes, their sets are intentionally curated to guide dancers through an inner experience—honouring the body’s natural rhythms and the intelligence within. Their offerings create safe, accessible spaces for people of all bodies, backgrounds, and experience levels to explore movement, presence, and connection. Rooted in play, precision, and deep listening, Sonic Sutra brings music that moves beyond entertainment—into healing and transformation.

events.long_description:
Join award-winning choir The Tudor Consort for our major project of the year! This will be the first time this groundbreaking work has been performed in Wellington for over a decade.


Juxtaposing Renaissance melodies and polyphony with the rich virtuosity and colour of Baroque instruments, intimate vocal solos with a choir and orchestra of unprecedented grandeur, and dazzling opulence with striking emotional and spiritual depth, this will be an unmissable performance

events.id: Sika Sound Journey-Raumati South Memorial Hall, 16 Tennis Court Rd, Raumati-Event Finder
events.name: Sika Sound Journey
events.venue: Raumati South Memorial Hall, 16 Tennis Court Rd, Raumati
events.long_description:
This powerful experience is like a soundtrack that is crafted to go with your life.

Something between an ancient ceremony and a movie soundtrack.

Please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket. Be prepared to drop into a deep space.

Door sales will be available if there is space. Advanced booking is recommended.

Sika's Sound Journeys are truly unique. They are sonic explorations that feature didgeridoos, drums, flutes, voice and orchestral elements. A collection of foraged sounds from objects he has recorded in nature, add even more textures. Many of his sounds are completely unrecognisable and abstract. Immersed in this cocoon of abstract sound, we can find ourselves in the most surprising places in our mind. In this timeless realm, beyond the normal limitations of rational reality, anything is possible.

An epic adventure deep inside yourself.

Journey to worlds within worlds on incredible sound waves.

Sika creates a safe space to relax deeply and connect with our inner guidance. This Sound Journey begins and ends with a short guided visualisation.

There will be two journeys with an interval. Most people choose to lie down, so once again, please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket to get really comfortable.

A journal is also recommended.

events.description:
Our major project for 2025 is the brilliant Vespro della Beata Vergine of 1610 by Claudio Monteverdi.
Featuring cornetti, dulcian, archlutes and recorders, this collection of music for the office of Vespers has not been performed here in Wellington for a decade.
We will be joined by top musicians from the NZSO and abroad for this sumptuous work N.B.
There will be a pre-concert talk at 7pm.

events.id: BANDIT QUEEN @ The Boathouse, Nelson-326 Wakefield Quay Nelson, Nelson Region 7010-Event Brite
events.name: BANDIT QUEEN @ The Boathouse, Nelson
events.venue: 326 Wakefield Quay Nelson, Nelson Region 7010
events.long_description:
BANDIT QUEEN is NZ's finest (likely only) tribute to the music of The Decemberists.A Tribute to the Decemberists? BUT WHO ARE THE DECEMBERISTS?
Hailing from Portland Oregon, The Decemberists is an indie-alt folk rock band that write epic songs and have 9 studio albums to their credit. They are renowned for their musical style and unique storytelling with many song lyrics based on historical incidents and folklore. Perhaps drawing musical influence from the likes of The Beatles, Tom Waits, REM, Morrisey, their songs are exquisitely constructed and effortlessly combine folk-rock with elements of pop creating the infectious sound that is The Decemberists.
And who is BANDIT QUEEN? Experienced Christchurch based musos - Tim Kent (vocals, acoustic guitar); Justin 'Rusty' White (lead guitar); Jo-Anne Davern Fuller (vocals, keyboard); Chiara Lowe (violin, vocals); Adam Lowe (bass); Mark Newburn (drums, percussion).
The members of BANDIT QUEEN are passionate about this project and invite you to come experience and enjoy the eclectic music of USA indie-rock band THE DECEMBERISTS.

events.id: Is It Off?-Hannah Playhouse, 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Is It Off?
events.venue: Hannah Playhouse, 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
Created and performed by Mamaeroa (Mo) Munn

This sold-out Pōneke favourite returns for one night only at Hannah Playhouse!

An oversharer with a splash of OCD, comedian, improviser and playwright Mo Munn was once called “unhinged” by a reviewer - and now she’s made it her whole personality! In her first solo hour, Mo squishes stand up, experimental and improvised comedy together for a rapid-fire whiplash of a show! Think one woman comedy buffet, packed with chaotic jokes, outlandish stories and a touch of spectacle. Fresh from debuting at the NZ International Comedy Fest, and taking home two comedy awards, Is it off? will keep audiences on their toes, delivering a comedy experience more hectic than a high school rave.

“… her show goes off in a very good way. It deserves to travel far and wide, as long as the oven is up for that." - John Smythe, Theatreview

" She jabs and slices at her audience and draws laughs instead of blood.... Thematically it's perfect" - Wellyott

General admission - pay what you can: $8 -$40

events.id: Daffodil Express 2025-Bunny Street, Wellington-Facebook
events.name: Daffodil Express 2025
events.venue: Bunny Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!
Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.
Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.
Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.
The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.
Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.
Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!
The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.
Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!
Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free
For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/
