events.id: Water Cast Pendants Taster - Spring-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Water Cast Pendants Taster - Spring
events.venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
events.long_description:
This is a super quick 3-hour session, and is great fun to do with family or friends.

Water casting is a really hands-on low-tech casting method that results in surprising and fun little forms that can be turned into pendants with amazing textures and shapes.

You will be guided through melting silver and pouring it into water to create little charms.

Experiment with pouring at different heights to create different shapes.
Choose one or a few of your favourites to have drilled and turn into simple pendants or earrings, or new charms for your bracelets!

We will use hardened jump rings to attach your water-cast pieces to either colourful cord or you can choose sterling silver chains which you can purchase for extra.

The technique will be demonstrated with important health and safety practices, then students will be guided to do at least a couple of casts, and should expect to have at least one successful item to clean up and finish in the class.

A basic amount of metal allowance of a small amount of silver is included in your course costs, and if your projects go over that amount you can pay for the metal you use on the day via internet banking or cash.

This course is open to complete beginners and advanced makers. Extra materials such as chains and findings are available to purchase.

For health and safety reasons class participants must wear sturdy, closed toe shoes and have their hair tied back.

events.long_description:
Te Motu Kairangi, with the support of Miramar & Maupuia Community Centre, warmly invites you to:
Monthly Flax Weaving Wānanga
Experience the joy of learning, sharing, and reconnecting with the art of weaving.
Whether you’re a first-time weaver or returning to refresh your skills, all are welcome. We’ll cover basic weaving techniques and tikanga (customs) and provide a supportive, creative space to connect with Māori arts and crafts alongside others.
Session Times
• Open session: 1:30pm – 5:00pm (pack down starts at 4:30pm)
What to Bring
• New weavers: 5–10 rau (blades) of harakeke, sharp scissors.
• An old towel
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
• Returning weavers: 30–40 rau of harakeke and your weaving tools
• Some tools are available to borrow
• Shared kai (snacks) welcome but not required
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
Koha appreciated, not required
If you would like to support the kaupapa, please email us at temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com for koha details.
Come and enjoy weaving, learning, and connection in a beautiful, relaxed setting.
Contact
via facebook
https://www.facebook.com/TeMotuKai

Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com
If you would like to koha to TMK, please email (Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com) for the account details.

events.id: Puku Rangi Tea – Rapa Nui Music & Dance Tour in Marlborough-5 Stephenson Street, Blenheim Central, Blenheim 7201, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Puku Rangi Tea – Rapa Nui Music & Dance Tour in Marlborough
events.venue: 5 Stephenson Street, Blenheim Central, Blenheim 7201, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Experience the vibrant culture of Easter Island as Puku Rangi Tea tours for the first time in Marlborough to closing the Welcoming Week Celebration!
Since 2012, they have been dedicated to preserving and showcasing traditional Rapa Nui music and dance. Their vibrant performances include the Hoko warrior dance, resonating with the spirit of the Māori Haka, storytelling through Takona body painting and ancestral narratives, Kai Kai string games and the rhythmic sounds of Tahitian ukulele and drums.
Puku Rangi Tea currently performs three shows a week at the Tahatai Hotel in Hanga Roa, Rapa Nui, and has participated in various festivals throughout its history, including:
Indigenous festival 2023–2024, San Juan de la Costa, Chile.
World Gathering of Folkloric Associations 2020, Lima, Peru.
International Festival 2018–2019, Málaga, Spain.
Chapultepec Forest Festival 2018, Mexico City, Mexico.
Second Workshop on Rapa Nui Music and Dance 2018, Mexico City, Mexico.
Rapa Nui Dance and Music Show 2018, Mexico City and Morelia, Michoacán, Mexico.
First Workshop on Rapa Nui Music and Dance 2017, Mexico City, Mexico.
Rapa Nui Dance and Music Show 2017, Mexico City, Mexico.
Indigenous festival 2016–2020, San Juan de la Costa, Chile.
Cultural Market 2017, Mexico City, Mexico.
12th Pacific Arts Festival 2016, Hagåtña, Guam.
Carnaval 2016, Arica, Chile.
Summer Festival 2016, Valdivia, Chile.
Oktoberfest Chile 2015–2017, Malloco, Chile.
Gala Puro Chile 2015, Miami, United States.
The tour holds significant cultural importance due to Rapa Nui deep ancestral connections with Aotearoa, offering a unique opportunity for cultural engagement and community connection.
Their itinerary includes high-profile engagements, such as:
Music Workshop on Friday 12 at 4pm - Koha Entry - RSVP Required
Dance Workshop on Friday 12 at 6pm - Koha Entry - RSVP Required
Concert: Live music and dances on Sunday 14 Spetember. Doors open at 3:30pm, Event start at 4pm
Koha - Entry - RSVP Required (Limited Capacity)
We are also excited to feature the local guest band "Matices", who will open the concert with a vibrant performance of live Andean and Latin American music.

events.id: Bailamos Bachata! Latin Dance Party (with free lesson)-39 Abel Smith St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Bailamos Bachata! Latin Dance Party (with free lesson)
events.venue: 39 Abel Smith St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Please note: the event is free but it can only continue if we support the Southern Cross by buying food or drinks

Wellington’s favourite monthly Bachata Latin dance party

Join us for an awesome mix of bachata, focusing on the best sensual tracks and remixes, along with salsa and a smattering of kizomba and zouk. We welcome everyone, from the absolute beginner to the most experienced dancer. We’re all about the joy of social dancing together.
And what makes a free party with great people even better? A free beginners’ bachata lesson with some of Wellington‘s best Latin dance teachers. If you’ve never danced bachata, Latin dance or even any other dance style before then this is the perfect lesson for you. We will have you dancing like a pro in no time!
Bailamos Bachata is hosted free of charge by the Southern Cross. They love the atmosphere we bring but we also need to support them in return. We’re asking everyone attending to purchase soft drinks, food or alcohol from the bar. It’s vital we show our gratitude.
1800-1830 social
1830-1900 free lesson
1900-2100 social
Q&A
Q. What is bachata?
A. Bachata is a popular and fun Latin couples dance. It started in the Dominican Republic, then travelled to Europe and the rest of the world. It now includes a wide range of music styles and dance influences and is still changing and evolving.
Q. I haven’t danced before, is that a problem?
A. Not at all! That’s exactly what the lesson is for – everyone has to start somewhere and we’re a very welcoming crowd for beginners.
Q. Is bachata a difficult dance to learn?
A. Its origins as a party/community dance mean the basics can be learnt quite quickly, so you’ll be enjoying yourself in no time.
Q. Who are the capital bachata collective?
A. We are the combined Wellington dance schools and people teaching bachata and we really want to share this dance with everyone. We love bachata, we love our community and we want to share it with you
￼
events.description:
Please note: the event is free but it can only continue if we support the Southern Cross by buying food or drinks Wellington’s favourite monthly Bachata Latin dance party Join us for an awesome mix of bachata, focusing on the best sensual tracks and remixes, along with salsa and a smattering of kizomba and zouk.
A free beginners’ bachata lesson with some of Wellington‘s best Latin dance teachers.
We will have you dancing like a pro in no time!
We are the combined Wellington dance schools and people teaching bachata and we really want to share this dance with everyone.
We love bachata, we love our community and we want to share it with you ￼

events.id: PIG DESTROYER-San Fran, Wellington-Ticket Master
events.name: PIG DESTROYER
events.venue: San Fran, Wellington
events.description:
PIG DESTROYER boil metal down to its muscle, sinew, and bone-razor-sharp guitar, percussive pummelling, and alone, stark howl-and use them to commit a vicious assault.
The lyrics paint loathsome, frightening images of pitch-black self-hatred and the frailty of the human experience.
These musical manifestations only serve to cement their already legendary status.
Having not been in Australia and New Zealand since 2008, PIG DESTROYER’s long overwaited return has just one goal.
To unnerve the unprepared with a deranged, grisly intensity which very few, if any, can match San Fran holds a Supervised License, meaning minors are welcome to attend events at San Fran so long as they are accompanied by a legal guardian at all times whilst at the venue.

events.id: Leadership And Management Part 2-AREA Meetings and Events, 1 O'Reily Ave, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Leadership And Management Part 2
events.venue: AREA Meetings and Events, 1 O'Reily Ave, Wellington
events.description:
Learn how to make the transition from buddy to boss and lead a successful team.
As John F. Kennedy once said, “leadership and learning are indispensable to each other”.
Our Leadership & Management courses are designed to help you get the best performance from yourself and your team, providing you with the skills and techniques to become better than you ever perceived you could be.
The Leadership & Management Part 2 workshop will equip leaders and managers with the skills to build high performing and highly motivated teams; the skills to communicate effectively as a leader, become more self-aware, provide coaching and mentoring, deal with conflict in a constructive and productive manner along with developing ways to solve problems as a team.
This workshop also gives participants an understanding of the key concepts of leadership and leadership styles along with how to choose and implement a leadership style that is authentic and beneficial to both the organisation and the teams they serve.

events.id: The Mind, Body, & Climate Change-Kelburn Parade, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: The Mind, Body, & Climate Change
events.venue: Kelburn Parade, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.long_description:
The Mind, Body, & Climate Change 
Explore how young minds can drive change by understanding the links between climate change, well-being, and action.

Free kai. Big ideas. Good vibes.
Ready to connect the dots between your own well-being and the planet’s future? We’re talking real talk, fresh perspectives, and a whole lot of inspiration — without the boring lecture vibe.
Devamrita Swami — world-travelling monk, renowned strategist, social observer, and all-round thought-provoker — is back at Vic Uni. He’s spoken at universities all over the globe, and now he’s here to flip the way you see climate action and mental health.
And yes… free plant-based dinner is on us:
– Loaded nachos (salsa, taco ‘meat’, sour ‘cream’ & ‘cheese’)
– Strawberry & peanut butter milkshakes
– Caramel & chocolate donuts
Come for the food, stay for the conversation. Vibe with good humans, share some laughs, and leave with fresh ideas you’ll actually want to act on.
When: Tues 16 Sept, 5:45 pm
Where: Vic Uni, Kelburn Parade — MacLaurin Building MCLT103 (up the steps from the Hub). We’ll have people outside pointing you in the right direction. Lost? Text us: +64 20 4191 5046
Click ‘Get Tickets’ to save your seat (and your donut).

events.id: Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré-34 Mulgrave Street, Thorndon, Wellington-Facebook
events.name: Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré
events.venue: 34 Mulgrave Street, Thorndon, Wellington
events.long_description:
The Futuna Lecture Series commenced in 2011 and has been one of the main annual events on the NZ Architectural calendar for the last 14 years. It is the Futuna Chapel Trust’s major fundraiser each year and attracts a large audience of architects, architectural designers, technicians, architecture and design students and interested members of the public. The Trust exists solely on koha/donations as well as financial support from selected sponsors and donors.
Our sponsors, Dulux NZ, APL, Plytech, Warren Trust and the Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington NZIA branches have continued their support for the Futuna Lecture Series 2025.
This year the Trust welcomes three new sponsors being Roofing Industries Limited, AGP and Big River Panels. The additional support of these new sponsors is very much appreciated and ensures that the Futuna Chapel Trust can continue to attract speakers to NZ of a similar calibre to that of the 2025 Futuna Lecture, Francis Kéré.
The Trust takes this opportunity to thank Metalcraft Roofing for their support of the Futuna Lecture Series from 2012 - 2024.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work and well as that of the Kéré Foundation.
The Trust will donate 20% of the ticket income to the Kéré Foundation to support the work of Francis Kéré in Gando, Burkina Faso.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. Please register using the ticket types of $10, $15, $25 or $30 GST inclusive. Booking fees are in addition to the ticket prices.
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when purchasing Architect tickets

events.id: Jenin Jenin Screening-2/57 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Jenin Jenin Screening
events.venue: 2/57 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
This spring from the 28th of August to the 2nd of October we will be screening a series of excellent Palestinian films, old and new, every week at two/fiftyseven on Willis Street, with ticket sales going to the Gazan mutual aid group The Sameer Project.
The Sameer Project is an on-the-ground aid organisation organised by Palestinians in the diaspora, which crowdfunds in order to provide tents, medical care and direct cash aid to those most affected in Gaza. They can be found on Instagram at @thesameerproject.
More information:
Jenin Jenin includes testimony from Jenin residents after the Israeli army’s Defensive Shield operation, during which the city and camp were the scenes of fierce fighting. The operation ended with Jenin flattened and scores of Palestinians killed. Palestinians as well as numerous human rights groups accused Israel of committing war crimes in the April 2002 attack on the refugee camp. The sad question forces itself on the spectator: What will become of a country, a people when its children are confronted with war and violence from a very early age?

events.id: Pastor From Gaza-St John's in the City Presbyterian Church, 170 Willis Street., Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Pastor From Gaza
events.venue: St John's in the City Presbyterian Church, 170 Willis Street., Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
St John’s is collaborating with Central Baptist to host this Pastor from Gaza, as he shares about being the Church amidst conflict.
Born and raised in Gaza, he now ministers across the Gaza and Middle East, providing pastoral support and practical aid to persecuted Christians, refugees, orphans, and widows.
This tour is not political—it is about the Body of Christ. The Pastor will share his own testimony, speak to the ongoing challenges faced by Christians in Gaza, and highlight his wider ministry in the Middle East. It is a message of hope, forgiveness, and perseverance—one that will challenge the Church in Aotearoa.
This event is to raise awareness of the spiritual and practical needs of believers in Gaza and the Middle East, as well as invite us to give in support of his ministry, with funds going directly to help persecuted Christians with food, shelter, and outreach.

events.id: St. Theresa's School Production 2025 - LEST WE FORGET-Otaihanga Road, Otaihanga 5036, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: St. Theresa's School Production 2025 - LEST WE FORGET
events.venue: Otaihanga Road, Otaihanga 5036, New Zealand
events.long_description: Set in both New Zealand and the narrow trenches of Gallipoli, Lest We Forget tells the powerful story of New Zealand civilians, soldiers and nurses who find courage, friendship and hope in the face of war. As letters from home arrive and battles rage on, they share laughter, sorrow, and dreams of returning to Aotearoa. This school production honours the Kiwi spirit and sacrifices made during one of our nation’s most defining campaigns. A moving tribute not to be missed.

events.id: Paint and Wine Night in Wellington - Your Friendly Cow-Cambridge Hotel, 28 Cambridge Terrace, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Paint and Wine Night in Wellington - Your Friendly Cow
events.venue: Cambridge Hotel, 28 Cambridge Terrace, Wellington
events.long_description:
The concept is simple - take a brush in one hand, a drink in the other and let’s paint a masterpiece!

Join us for a creative night of drinking and painting in the heart of Wellington! No previous painting experience necessary. Get your creative juices flowing and your brush strokes going!

Drinks: No drinks are included in the ticket price, but drinks are available for purchase.

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website.

At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

events.id: Manage Your Expectations-Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Manage Your Expectations
events.venue: Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington
events.long_description:
Created and Performed by Eliza Sanders
Produced by House of Sand
Directed by Charley Allanah

You decide the ending…

Solo performer Eliza Sanders has a simple task: to tell you everything that will happen in the show, so you can decide if you would like to see it. Nothing is ever so simple.

This genre-defying work of dance, theatre, live film, clown and absurd philosophising takes the idea of the ‘trigger warning’ to its absurdist extreme to question how ‘informed’ consent can really be, and asking ‘How much do you really want to know?’

Created and performed by multi-award-winning maverick of the stage Eliza Sanders, Manage Your Expectations helps us to see the limits of the power to communicate and our failures to say what we mean. Through movement, multimedia, and razor-sharp wit, it examines the impossibility of perfect communication, musing on the influence of context, identity and personal history while creating something beautiful from our collective mess.

“Clever, witty, evocative, subversive, immersive, despairing, poignant, personal and universal” — Deirdre Tarrant, Theatreview

“Beautifully vulnerable” – Chloe Jaques, Theatreview, 2024

Full of vigour, energy, chaos and a hint of confrontation, Manage Your Expectations is a mind (and body) bending show about how we connect in an increasingly complex world. And you decide the ending…

Content warning: this show contains explicit content, mild coarse language, heavy nudity, themes of abortion and rape.

WINNER: Best Performer, Whangārei Fringe 2024
WINNER: Outstanding Solo Performance, NZ Fringe 2024
WINNER: San Diego Tour Ready, NZ Fringe 2024
NOMINATION: Best in Fringe, NZ Fringe 2024
NOMINATION: Most Innovative Work, NZ Fringe 2024
NOMINATION: Sydney Tour Ready, NZ Fringe 2024
NOMINATION: Auckland Tour Ready, NZ Fringe 2024
NOMINATION: Melbourne Tour Ready, NZ Fringe 2024
NOMINATION: Adelaide Tour Ready, NZ Fringe 2024
NOMINATION: Most Original Production, Wellington Theatre Awards 2024

Tues 16 – Sat 20 Sept 2025
Q&A and Choose Your Price Night: Wed 17 Sept
Relaxed Performance: Thurs 18 Sept
Circa Two
Tues – Fri 7.30pm, Sat 20 Sept 2.00pm & 7.30pm
Show Duration: 75 minutes no interval
Recommended Age 16+

events.id: Compliance made SME-asy: Health & Safety Essentials with MD Safety Consulting-Holloway Street, Carterton 5713, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Compliance made SME-asy: Health & Safety Essentials with MD Safety Consulting
events.venue: Holloway Street, Carterton 5713, New Zealand
events.description:
Are you a small business owner or manager wanting to improve your health and safety practices but not sure where to start?
Join Mallory from MD Safety Consulting Ltd, for a 90-minute interactive workshop designed specifically for small businesses like yours.
This workshop will cut through the confusion and provide practical, easy-to-implement strategies to help you meet legal requirements, keep your team safe, and build a strong safety culture.
What You’ll Learn: Health & Safety Compliance & Documentation – The essential documents you need (without unnecessary admin) Hazard & Risk Management – How to identify risks, assess them, and control them effectively Worker Engagement & Training – Simple ways to involve your team and ensure proper safety training Emergency Procedures – Creating an easy-to-follow emergency plan tailored to your business Incident Reporting & Investigation – How to report and learn from incidents to prevent future harm What You’ll Get: Practical tools & templates to apply immediately in your business Resource sheet linking to free NZ-based safety tools A chance to ask questions and get expert guidance Mallory understands the challenges of running a small business, and is passionate about helping business owners navigate health and safety in a way that is simple, effective, and realistic.
Whether you're starting from scratch or refining your current systems, this workshop will give you actionable steps to improve safety and compliance in your workplace.

events.id: Achieving Cashflow Freedom-322 Hardy Street Nelson, Nelson 7010-Event Brite
events.name: Achieving Cashflow Freedom
events.venue: 322 Hardy Street Nelson, Nelson 7010
events.long_description:
Cashflow freedom means your business delivers sufficient cash for you to live your desired lifestyle. In turbulent times, this can feel increasingly unattainable, but there are many things you can take control of to increase the odds.
By attending this seminar you’ll:
Learn how a tougher economy could impact your business
Understand how to better plan for the ‘what ifs’
Discover multiple ways to increase sales outcomes
Understand how measurement improves management
Learn the processes required to boost your cash levels
Following the webinar, we’ll send attendees a Guide to Cashflow and Cashflow Health Check to ensure you take control of your cashflow and achieve cashflow freedom.

events.id: Resilience and Emissions Reduction Workshop for Not-For-Profits | Blenheim-Blenheim, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Resilience and Emissions Reduction Workshop for Not-For-Profits | Blenheim
events.venue: Blenheim, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Ready your not-for-profit for the future
Do you know you need to take action to address climate change but don’t know where to start?
Do you want to strengthen your organisations’ planning and readiness for change?
Do you want practical tools and support to measure, assess, and report on your organisations’ impact?

In partnership with Rātā Foundation, our Earth+ Resilience and Emissions Reduction programme has been designed to flip the script on climate change, centering your organisation as agents of change and kitting you with the tools, support and community to make a difference; and it’s free of charge!
About the programme
With the support of the Terra Nova team and other programme participants, you will be guided to identify how your organisation is uniquely placed to contribute to the resilience and wellbeing of people and planet, and the opportunities and obstacles to creating positive change.
The programme is accessible and suitable for everyone, from those just starting on the journey, to those who have steps in place but are looking to gain access to further resources. This programme is not intended to add extra workload or deliverables for your organisation, it is an offer of support to integrate an Earth+ approach into your BAU; an answer to the question “what can we do about climate change?”
We know that every organisation’s capacity is different, so our support is available for you to utilise it when you need it until the end of 2025. This includes:
Access to a dedicated online community where you can connect with the Terra Nova team, other Rātā grantees and specialised partners. Ask questions, find resources and share your journey.
A toolkit of resources and impact sessions to develop your knowledge and connect you with the expertise and support to build resilience and tackle change in a range of impact areas.
Complementary access to the Cogo carbon emissions measurement tool, providing you the ability to quantify and report on your emissions impact and providing recommended actions for emissions reduction and cost savings, in an easy-to-use format.
It begins with a 1-day interactive workshop to kick things off. By the end of the workshop, you will walk away:
Feeling more empowered about the future, with a deeper understanding of resilience and climate change as it relates to your organisation’s context.
Having explored how you can make change positive and achievable, centered on the needs of your community and team. 
With free access to Cogo carbon manager, an emissions profile, report of your carbon footprint and practical action you can take to reduce your emissions.
Having built a network of support and gained free-to-use practical tools and templates.
Note: we will be running multiple workshops throughout the year; you only need to attend one workshop to join the programme. If you prefer an alternate date, please head to our Humanitix profile to find the corresponding event. 
The programme is fully funded for not-for-profit organisations and registrations are now open for 2025! Register for the programme and secure your spot in a workshop through this Humanatix event, and a member of the Terra Nova team will be in touch to confirm your enrollment. For more information about the programme and workshop, visit the Terra Nova website.
We look forward to welcoming you into our community of changemakers!

events.id: Treasury Guest Lecture with Michael Keen: IN-PERSON attendance-1 The Terrace Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
events.name: Treasury Guest Lecture with Michael Keen: IN-PERSON attendance
events.venue: 1 The Terrace Wellington, Wellington 6011
events.long_description:
Join us for our special Fiscal Policy for the Future seminar
New Zealand faces significant long-term fiscal challenges, including the rising costs associated with an ageing population, increasing demand for public services, and the need to adapt to a changing global economy. These pressures will require careful planning to ensure the sustainability of government finances while maintaining fairness and efficiency in the tax system.
Inland Revenue’s draft Long-Term Insights Briefing explores these issues by asking critical questions about the future shape and scale of our tax system. Similarly, the Treasury’s Long-Term Fiscal Statement highlights the importance of future-proofing our tax framework and other broader policy settings to address these challenges.
Join us for this seminar delivered by a highly regarded economist and expert in tax policy and administration, and a prolific author, Michael Keen, as he shares his insights on future proofing our tax system.
This will be a hybrid event, and we encourage you to attend it in person for an opportunity to engage in a discussion on all those issues with our guest speaker.
About this event
This will be a hybrid event. Please use this site to register if you plan to attend it in person.
If you would like to attend it virtually, please use THIS LINK to register.
The Tax Policy Charitable Trust has arranged Mick’s visit to New Zealand. The Trust was established to support leading tax policy thinking in New Zealand. You can read about the Trust’s work here.
About the presenter
Michael (Mick) Keen is a former Deputy Director of the Fiscal Affairs Department at the International Monetary Fund, where for over twenty years he played a central role in shaping and delivering IMF policies and advice on tax matters.
He has advised finance ministries in all parts of the world, including missions to over forty countries, and led the preparation of influential papers for the G20 and the Executive Board of the IMF.
Before joining the Fund, Mick was Professor of Economics at the universities of Essex (UK), Queens (Canada) and Kyoto, and is now Ushioda Fellow at the University of Tokyo.
Mick was the keynote speaker at the 2014 conference on the Future of Tax Administration in New Zealand and has provided peer review for Inland Revenue’s previous Long-Term Insights Briefing.
Mick has jointly authored, with Joel Slemrod, Rebellion, Rascals and Revenue – an entertaining account of how history illuminates the perennial challenges and timeless principles of taxation—and how the past holds clues to solving the tax problems of today.
About this seminar series
New ideas, innovative concepts, research evidence and expert advice are all crucial to stimulate and inform the Treasury’s economic analysis and advice. Our current theme for guest lectures - Fiscal Policy for the Future - explores the role of stabilising, sustainable and effective fiscal policy. Speakers provide insights into how fiscal policy can be designed to support government to meet its current and future objectives and obligations while adapting to changing circumstances and delivering value to the New Zealand public.
Fiscal policy has a stabilising role in helping to smooth the business cycle, while sustainability in fiscal policy is foundational for resilience to both shocks and longstanding challenges, such as climate change, technological advancements, and demographic trends. Ensuring effective and value for money expenditure is important so that fiscal policy contributes to the living standards of New Zealanders, both now and in the future.
Please note that the views, opinions, findings, and conclusions expressed in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series are those of the individual presenters. They do not necessarily reflect the views of the New Zealand Treasury or the New Zealand Government.
For updates and our latest research visit: www.treasury.govt.nz
Keep in touch
If you would like to be the first to hear about our upcoming events in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series, please SUBSCRIBE to stay up to date.

events.id: Managing for value: building a strong financial advice business-Wellington-33 Military Road Boulcott Wellington, Wellington 5010-Event Brite
events.name: Managing for value: building a strong financial advice business-Wellington
events.venue: 33 Military Road Boulcott Wellington, Wellington 5010
events.long_description:
Building a valuable financial advice business means you have a resilient business to support your clients and a strong asset. Transactions – acquisition and disposal support the long-term growth and sustainability of financial advice provider businesses. Transactions take many forms, going concerns regularly acquire and dispose of clients, business units, lines of business, have investors buy-in, bring key staff together – and split businesses up. Only a small number of our transactions are the classic market exit.
Our aim is to spend time talking with advisers about how to grow their business and manage for value – making their business more valuable by explicitly thinking about valuation in addition to the other metrics such as profit and cashflow.

events.id: Wellington Timebank fundraiser screening of Tinā-7A Rintoul St, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Wellington Timebank fundraiser screening of Tinā
events.venue: 7A Rintoul St, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Get your tickets here - https://events.humanitix.com/wtb-fundraiser-screening-of...
Join us for this special screening of this award winning Aotearoa-made film - Tinā (2024). If you missed it in the cinemas the first time round, you can now watch it from the comfort of the Newtown Community Centre!
Doors open at 5pm
Film starts at 6pm (running time is 2 hours 4 minutes)
Tickets are just $25 waged / $20 unwaged (all tickets include snacks) and proceeds go toward keeping your Timebank in operation.
About the film:
Award-winning writer/director Miki Magasiva (The Panthers, We Are Still Here) makes his feature debut with Tinā (Samoan for "mother"). Samoan music teacher Mareta (Anapela Polataivao) is plunged into grief after losing her daughter in the Christchurch quakes. Mareta takes a relieving role at an elite private school, where she inspires her students to perform at a big choral competition. In the trailer Mareta faces a condescending interview at Saint Francis, and her growing relationship with "spoiled, rich kids" annoys a family member. Tinā was chosen to open the 2024 Hawai’i International Film Festival.

events.id: Over and Out-1 Kent Ter, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Over and Out
events.venue: 1 Kent Ter, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
"NEVER become a truck driver!" - A young Jackson Burling took that advice, avoiding the fork in the road, but now, after a long and gruelling two year slog in the arts industry he must confront that age old question: "why not, Dad?" - and take us along for the ride.
In ‘Over and Out’, premiering at the 2025 TAHI Festival, he’ll bring you a REAL interview, a BIG character, and even bigger QUESTIONS to the stage. One actor. 50 minutes. Countless emotional potholes
Along the way, we get a rare look into the gritty, heartfelt, and often-overlooked life of one of Aotearoa’s essential workers — the truck driver
Is the open road calling — or is the stage his true destination?
Buckle up. This is verbatim theatre with serious mileage.
Created and Performed by Jackson Burling
Directed by Simon Leary | Produced by Tom Smith

Fresh voices, bold stories. HATCH puts emerging talent in the spotlight.
TAHI Festival’s student showcase, HATCH, champions our next generation of solo performers.
In partnership with Te Auaha, Toi Whakaari: NZ Drama School, and Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington, HATCH supports students through workshops, mentorship, and creative development, culminating in a high-energy showcase at BATS Theatre.

events.name: Hatch Showcase
events.venue: BATS Theatre, 1 Kent Tce, Wellington
events.long_description:
Fresh voices, bold stories. HATCH puts emerging talent in the spotlight!

TAHI Festival’s student showcase, HATCH, champions our next generation of solo performers. In partnership with Te Auaha, Toi Whakaari: NZ Drama School, and Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington, HATCH supports students through workshops, mentorship, and creative development, culminating in a high-energy showcase at BATS Theatre. Show info below.

Cursed Child: The return of Mr Haki
Written and performed by Leia Edmonds
Mr Haki is Leia’s childhood imaginary friend. He returns from the grave to confront her about his death. Cursed Child: The return of Mr Haki is a funny, slightly creepy, and nostalgic tale about the mind of a strange little girl. Contains mental health themes, and depictions of injury or medical distress.

HĀNGĪ PANTS
Written and performed by Waikamania Seve
It's 9:04pm, a Saturday like any other. Scandaleyes smeared on, soju burning sweet, cherry pomegranate nicotine clouding the air. K Road’s about to come alive, but Hāngī Pants is already unpacking the mess. Her lovers, her losses, her lust. Contains flashing lights, course language, themes of sexual assault, substance abuse, and eating disorders; and depictions of sex and semi-nudity.

Warm Night At Normal School
Written and performed by Gabriel Murphy
Gabriel missions across the sticky floors and strobe lights of the school disco to ask the girl he likes to dance with him. But it’s not as easy as it sounds. Recommended for audiences aged 13+. Contains flashing lights and some coarse language.

Enter: Child
Written and performed by Aroha Morrison
Wide-eyed, happy to be there, and - well - utterly clueless. Child leads with curiosity - will you follow?

Lost Memory
Written and performed by George Long
A man is trying to tell the story of meeting someone really important. But unfortunately life changes over time.

Show title to come
Written and performed by Charlie Roigard.
Show info to come.

events.id: Paint and Wine Night in Wellington - Piha Sunset-Hotel Bristol, 131 - 133 Cuba St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Paint and Wine Night in Wellington - Piha Sunset
events.venue: Hotel Bristol, 131 - 133 Cuba St, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
The concept is simple - take a brush in one hand, a drink in the other and let’s paint a masterpiece!

Join us for a creative night of drinking and painting in the heart of Wellington! No previous painting experience necessary. Get your creative juices flowing and your brush strokes going!

Drinks: No drinks are included in the ticket price, but drinks are available for purchase.

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website.

events.id: Impactful Leadership-Level 22, NTT Tower 157 Lambton Quay Wellington, Wellington Region 6011-Event Brite
events.name: Impactful Leadership
events.venue: Level 22, NTT Tower 157 Lambton Quay Wellington, Wellington Region 6011
events.long_description:
Impactful Leadership:
What do horses, mules and the All Blacks have in common? Hear a true expert break-down what really works when it comes to impactful leadership.
Welcome to the final conversation in our Women in Business series: four events that bring you important conversations led by Women in Business and heard by everyone. In partnership with Forsyth Barr, this bar-setting series is bringing hard-hitting topics into the conversational spotlight.
What good leadership looks like has changed, but many of the methods we rely on to deliver it haven’t. This conversation will showcase what horses can teach us about impactful leadership in modern workplaces, and how anyone can turn those lessons into action that delivers.
Why be part of this conversation?
In this thought-provoking session, BBC journalist-turned-leadership coach Janine Sudbury will share how she discovered what really works in leadership development, and why traditional approaches often fall short.
You’ll take away insights including:
The three secrets of the horse whisperer that unlock authentic, presence-based leadership
How to overcome Imposter Syndrome and People Pleasing to lead with clarity and confidence
Why horses give the most honest feedback—and how that feedback creates lasting breakthroughs
Who’s the speaker?
Janine Sudbury is the founder of Impact Leadership and the creator of a truly unique experiential leadership programme that swaps the boardroom for the paddock. specialises in helping women overcome Imposter Syndrome and People Pleasing Syndrome to lead with more confidence, clarity, and authenticity.
With powerful insights and unforgettable stories, including her work with former All Blacks coach Steve Hansen, Janine invites you to lead with more purpose, presence, and impact.
What’s in-store:
5:15-5:30pm – Arrival/networking
5:30-6:15pm – Janine Sudbury speaks
6:15-6:30pm – Q&A
6:30-7:30pm – Networking with drinks & canapes
Business card prize draw:
Attend the event and go in the draw to win a “New BMW for a Weekend” and a “New MINI for a Weekend” from Continental Cars BMW and Wellington MINI Garage.
This event is part of the Women in Business chapter from our “Join the Conversation” series - 4 events that spotlight important topics through conversation, led by the amazing women driving change within them.
Attend other events in the series:
17 July: Making money in the mess - How every woman can financially thrive in messy economic times
7 August: Strengths & Superpowers - Personal branding isn’t showing off - it’s taking ownership over how you’re perceived. Join a Masterclass in making yours standout among the rest
20 August: 3 Gals, One Beehive – live! - Hear three leading women take a week in politics, and turn it into the unfiltered commentary that you wish you’d hear on the 6 o’clock news.

events.id: Chain Maille Course-61/69 Abel Smith Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Chain Maille Course
events.venue: 61/69 Abel Smith Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Our medieval materials expert Achille is ready to be your chain maille master. In this seven class course you will hone in on the chain weaves that incite awe and be bestowed with the agency to create a wearable piece or majestic object of your own design. On the mysterious journey towards mastery, Achille will take you through everything from the dexterity of proper ring closing, to practicing resolve through the depths of theory and mathematics that allow you to design and execute a piece of your very own creation. This is the perfect course to begin your foray into the craft of chain maille.
This course it taught by medieval enthusiast Achille. He is a creature of curiosity and crepes, having spent the last 14 years skulking around the capital publishing “woke leftist paper” as a founder of 5ever books. He has conquered our hearts, minds, and the specialty cheese departments of the local supermarkets. Achille is a master of chain maille, now offering to teach his craft to those willing to take up the challenge.
Some materials and tools are supplied. Depending on the project you choose to create there may be extra material costs, as well as the option to purchase tools for personal use. You are welcome to bring your own bent nose pliers and wire cutters if you have them.
There are variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances! Note that this ticket is a commitment to the entire seven week course. No chain maille experience is required, just a will to delve into the depths of metal weaves. If you're unsure about committing to this craft, perhaps keep an eye out for a one off 101 chain maille class that may come in the future.
Course Outline:
Week 01 - 18th September
101: Basic Skills and Discovery
At this class we'll explore the basics of good chain maille practice.
Opening & closing rings properly
Trying out some simple structures
Begin exploring material options and how to make your own rings
Homework: keep an eye out for recycled or foraged materials that could be utilised in chain maille
Week 02 - 25th September
Play and Exploration
Gathering inspiration and looking into methods for individual projects
Playing with recycled & foraged materials
Homework: Choose a weave from the library to try out at home or explore during the next class
Week 03 - 2nd October
Mathematics of chain maille design, theory, and history.
Math of designing chain maille
Theory & pre-planning
Discussion about ideas for individual projects
Identify materials needed to execute individual designs
Homework: Choose your individual project, identify what materials you will need, and how we will source/make them.
Week 04 - 16th October
By this class you will have you project plan down. We'll be collecting/ making our materials or beginning the execution of our projects with the guidance of Achille.
Week 05 & 06 - 23rd & 30th October
These classes will be open working times to make use of tools in class, ask Achille questions or help with troubleshooting, and to share our progress, challenges, and solutions with each other.
Week 07 - 6th November
At this final class we will make finishing touches to our projects and celebrate our creations together! Perhaps including a catwalk of our chain maille wares, and sharing kai.

events.id: Book Launch - South by South by Charles Ferrall-Unity Books, 57 Willis St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Book Launch - South by South by Charles Ferrall
events.venue: Unity Books, 57 Willis St, Wellington
events.long_description:
Join us to celebrate the publication of Charles Ferrall's South by South: New Zealand and the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration. The book will be launched by Harry Ricketts.

- Thursday 18 September, 6pm
- Unity Books Wellington
- Free event – all welcome!

Joseph Kinsey is not a name many of us know – or not as well as we know the name Robert Falcon Scott. But from his base in Christchurch, Kinsey – book and art collector, philanthropist, science enthusiast, businessman – forged deep connections with the Antarctic expeditions and the explorers themselves through his tireless work as the agent for various expeditions. Two other New Zealanders also formed close friendships: Charles Bowen, a former politician, and Wellington lawyer Leonard Tripp, to whom Shackleton declared: ‘I love you as David and Jonathan loved.’

South by South tells the story of New Zealand’s role in ‘the Heroic Age’, that wave of exploration beginning at the end of the nineteenth century in which men set out to traverse the continent of Antarctica and, if they survived, to bring home their findings. The members of this New Zealander triumvirate were all believers in the British Empire, but the southern voyages were to an uninhabited land.

South by South brings to light many letters, newspaper articles, and pieces of official correspondence, much of which has not been published before, during the five expeditions of 1901–1916: the Discovery, Nimrod, Terra Nova, Aurora, and Endurance. In particular, Scott’s letters to Kinsey and Shackleton’s to Tripp tell of their hope, despair, exhaustion, and deep gratitude for their friendship. What they and the explorers wrote was influenced by nineteenth-century adventure stories which conveyed the Imperialist ideals of the time. If the impending conflict of 1914–18 was a very ‘literary war’, this was a very literary exploration.

Charles Ferrall is an associate professor at Te Herenga Waka–Victoria University of Wellington. Among his books are Modernist Writing and Reactionary Politics (2001); The Trials of Eric Mareo (2002), co-written with Rebecca Ellis; East by South: China in the Australasian Imagination (2006), co-edited with Paul Millar and Keren Smith; Juvenile Literature and British Society 1850–1950 (2009), co-written with Anna Jackson; Henry Lawson in New Zealand (2012); How We Remember: New Zealanders and the First World War (2014), co-edited with Harry Ricketts; and Remembering Gallipoli: Interviews with New Zealand Gallipoli Veterans (2015), co-edited with Christopher Pugsley.

Cover photograph: The ship Discovery leaving Lyttelton Harbour, 1901. Alexander Turnbull Library, Wellington, New Zealand
Cover design: Spencer Levine
events.description:

- Thursday 18 September, 6pm - Unity Books Wellington - Free event – all welcome!

events.id: Kotahitanga: Artist Series - Riki Gooch and Bennett Pomana-Wellington Museum, 3 Jervois Quay, Queens Wharf, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Kotahitanga: Artist Series - Riki Gooch and Bennett Pomana
events.venue: Wellington Museum, 3 Jervois Quay, Queens Wharf, Wellington
events.long_description:
Join Te Waka Huia for the final Kotahitanga event featuring a collaborative response to He Kura Toi Tangata from Wellington taonga Riki Gooch and Bennett Pomana.

Be prepared for textured sound and thought gymnastics with Riki on the drums and Bennett on the mic, closing out the series with one epic jam from these two legends.

5:30pm Doors open, bar open
6pm Artist response begins
6:30pm Interval
6:45pm Artist Q&A
7pm Closing Karakia and time to explore He Kura Toi Tangata exhibition
8pm Bar closes, event ends

About Riki Gooch

Dr Riki Neihana Gooch lives in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Aotearoa. His work spans multiple disciplines, including composition, performance, sound art, production, and academic research. He has led and conducted large-scale ensemble projects, performed in a wide range of collaborative settings, and created work for both recorded and live contexts. His ongoing projects include solo and group performances, conduction ensembles, DJ sets, and sound-based installations. He is also involved in cultural leadership and mentorship roles, holding wānanga and contributing to intergenerational knowledge exchange within the arts.


About Bennett Pomana

Bennett Pomana (Te Aitanga-a-Māhaki, Ngāi Tāmanuhiri) is a musician raised in Upper Hutt, with roots in Tūranganui-a-Kiwa. A longtime contributor to Aotearoa’s hip hop legacy, he has been part of pioneering groups including Upper Hutt Posse and Dam Native. His work is deeply influenced by his Māori identity, drawing inspiration from whakapapa, lived experience, and the ongoing pursuit of justice and expression through sound.


This event has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.

events.long_description:
Created and performed by Kristyl Neho
Tangihanga is a solo drama-comedy centred around Jess - a devoted daughter whose father, Karanipa, has passed away. As Jess’ whānau gathers at the marae to mourn, tensions rise, secrets are revealed, and long-held family dynamics begin to unravel.
Neho masterfully embodies over 30 characters, capturing the complexity of grief, cultural identity, and the strength of whānau. This bold, emotionally charged, and often hilarious performance speaks to the heart of Aotearoa.

events.id: Breathwork: A Gentle Reset-Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Breathwork: A Gentle Reset
events.venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
Breathwork: A Gentle Reset

Take a pause from the noise of daily life.

This breathwork journey begins with gentle movement to awaken the body and open the breath. Through slow, mindful stretches, we begin softening tension and grounding into the present.

You’ll then be guided through two styles of breathwork — each offering a unique pathway inward. There’s no pressure or expectation, just the freedom to explore what feels right for you:

A dynamic, connected breath for those who wish to build energy, move emotion, or break through internal blockages

A slow, rhythmic breath for those seeking stillness, calm, and deeper grounding

Both approaches invite a sense of spaciousness — physically, mentally, and emotionally — while supporting nervous system balance and inner clarity.

To gently close the session, we’ll move into a quiet, nurturing meditation to support integration and leave you feeling steady, clear, and connected.

Afterwards, stay and enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert, lovingly prepared to complement the experience — because healing is also about how we feed and care for ourselves.

Why Breathwork?

Breathwork has helped so many shift from a state of tension and overwhelm into a place of ease, clarity, and resilience — often after just one session. It’s a simple, powerful practice that reconnects you to your body, your breath, and your inner stillness.

You’ll leave feeling more grounded, more present, and more like yourself again.

Meet Karla, your host
Karla is a breathwork and trauma-somatic facilitator based in Aotearoa (New Zealand), originally from Malta. With over a decade of experience in Reiki and three years facilitating trauma-informed, science-based breathwork, Karla combines holistic tools, meditation, and conscious breathing to support nervous system regulation and deep emotional healing. Her offerings help release stored trauma, reduce stress and anxiety, and activate oxytocin—the “love hormone”—fostering connection, vitality, and a sense of wholeness. She currently holds regular classes, workshops, and transformative retreats that nurture the mind, body, and spirit.

events.id: Humans: Why & What To Do-Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Humans: Why & What To Do
events.venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
Humans: Why & What To Do
An evening of inspiration & indulgence! Talk by Devamrita Swami followed by a plant-powered dinner & dessert.

We’re the most connected generation in history — and somehow the loneliest. We’ve built more technology than any civilisation before us — and still can’t solve our basic problems. We talk endlessly about progress — while the planet burns and mental health plummets.

What if the trouble isn’t just what we’re doing… but that we’ve forgotten why we’re doing it?

In this bold talk, Devamrita Swami — a world-traveling monk, strategist, and social critic — unpacks the mess we’re in and asks the questions most of us avoid: Why are we here? And what should we actually be doing about it?

Afterwards, stick around for a plant-based dinner and dessert — fresh, colourful, and made to share. Grab a plate, grab a seat, and dive into real conversations with people who are curious, open-minded, and up for something different.

Meet Devamrita Swami, your host
Devamrita Swami is an educator, author, and monk who has spent over forty years exploring and sharing the wisdom of bhakti-yoga. He brings ancient Vedic teachings to life, effortlessly navigating the latest research in archaeology, consciousness, ancient history, neuroscience, social science, and psychology. Author of Searching for Vedic India and Hiding in Unnatural Happiness, he combines philosophy with practical insights on happiness, wellbeing, and personal fulfillment. For anyone seeking to channel the human drive for fulfilment in a meaningful and sustainable way, Devamrita Swami offers clear, engaging, and indispensable wisdom.

Talk by Devamrita Swami followed by a plant-powered dinner & dessert.
What if the trouble isn’t just what we’re doing… but that we’ve forgotten why we’re doing it?
In this bold talk, Devamrita Swami — a world-traveling monk, strategist, and social critic — unpacks the mess we’re in and asks the questions most of us avoid: Why are we here?
And what should we actually be doing about it?
Meet Devamrita Swami, your host Devamrita Swami is an educator, author, and monk who has spent over forty years exploring and sharing the wisdom of bhakti-yoga.

events.id: CMNZ Series From Scratch-Public Trust Hall, 131-135, Lambton Quay, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: CMNZ Series From Scratch
events.venue: Public Trust Hall, 131-135, Lambton Quay, Wellington
events.long_description:
New Zealand’s oldest and most avant-garde chamber music ensemble, From Scratch, has been performing nationally and internationally since 1974, principally under the leadership of sound and intermedia artist Phil Dadson.

From Scratch have developed an original and innovative sound/performance style that includes large sculptural invented instruments (primarily percussion), and innovative hocket-style rhythms – where the performers’ individual parts interlock to create complex rhythmic and melodic structures.

The current collective core-group consists of Adrian Croucher, Shane Currey, Phil Dadson, Darryn Harkness and Chris O'Connor.

events.long_description:
Pamela Browne has organised a 25 year reunion for her four best friends from High School. From the moment Kay, now a chocoholic gun-toting funeral director arrives, the wheels begin falling off Pamela’s meticulously planned weekend.
Added to the mix is Sandy, who is now a Nun, Dianne, married the school nerd and is a mother of eight sons, Rachel, a runaway teenager on a mission to dig up some dirt on her mother, and Shaun, the greasy motel janitor, who ends up in a compromising position in the ladies’ wardrobe.
Guns, gags, cuffs, crucifixes, sleaze-balls , slander, pizza and pinot – everything you need for a great weekend reunion!

events.id: Wunderhorse-Meow Nui, 92 Vivian Street, Te Aro, Wellington, 6011, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Wunderhorse
events.venue: Meow Nui, 92 Vivian Street, Te Aro, Wellington, 6011, Wellington
events.long_description:
Handsome Tours are pleased to present Wunderhorse in Australia + New Zealand in 2025!

Wunderhorse are Jacob Slater, Harry Fowler, Peter Woodin & Jamie Staples. 2022 saw the release of their debut album Cub, a collection of songs which found fans in Zane Lowe, NME, and BBC Radio 1, and took the band on tour with the likes of Fontaines D.C., Pixies, Sam Fender, and Foals, whilst also selling out their own headline slots along the way. Midas is out now.

Adopting an organic, unpolished recording process, Midas captures the visceral atmosphere of Wunderhorse’s raucous live performances. “We wanted it to sound like your face is pressed up against the amp,” frontman Jacob Slater told The Guardian. “No frills, no polish – just pure, uncut rock’n’roll.”
Indeed, the album’s rugged hooks, unfiltered noise, and fierce melodic sensitivity set Wunderhorse up for a year that will see them firmly established as an endlessly addictive and rousing generational talent.

events.name: etu | Wellington
events.venue: San Fran, Wellington
events.long_description:
San Fran
AUSTRALIA/NZ
PRESENT
ETU
SUNFLOWER TOUR
Thursday 18 September 2025 Doors 7:30 PM

etu is a Tongan-American singer, songwriter, and storyteller whose music bridges cultures and generations. Blending island harmonies with mainstream aura, etu’s sound is deeply rooted yet powerfully contemporary. His debut album ‘Sunflower’ is a heartfelt exploration of identity, belonging, and gratitude — a celebration of Pacific pride and resilience. etu’s performances are more than just about the music — they’re tailored spiritual & personal experiences that uplift, connect, and inspire. From concerts in the South Pacific to major festival stages, etu is on a mission to bring light to his people and share their stories with the world.


"This tour is more than me playing songs – it’s about bringing the spirit of the islands to every stage," says etu. "I want people to leave feeling seen, uplifted, and part of something bigger than themselves." 

With songs in English, Tongan, Samoan, Fijian, and Chuukese, Sunflower is a rich tapestry of sound and storytelling – a heartfelt exploration of belonging, gratitude, and resilience.

You can’t teach an old dog new tricks... can you? Biting satire and theatre wizardry fuse in a comically inventive roller-coaster about the fear of irrelevance and the healing power of an animal. Award-winning actor, writer, and solo performer, Stephen Papps, plays twelve characters with beguiling virtuosity, in this gloriously funny solo tour de force about a man who loses face in a desperate attempt to regain his relevance.

“It’s impressive for a performer to embody a big range of characters ... well-written and full of humorous insights and revelations ... glorious!” – Cate Prestige, Theatreview.

Audience care: Recommended for audiences aged 13+

events.id: Celebrating 132 years of women’s suffrage — special lunchtime tour and kōrero-Cellar-Cafe, Molesworth St, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Celebrating 132 years of women’s suffrage — special lunchtime tour and kōrero
events.venue: Cellar-Cafe, Molesworth St, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Join our kaimahi for a special lunchtime tour and kōrero, highlighting the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition | Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine, which paved the way for women’s suffrage in Aotearoa.
Tour and kōrero
Mark your calendars for 19 September, the anniversary of the 1893 Electoral Act that granted New Zealand women the right to vote in parliamentary elections.
To celebrate Suffrage Day, join a 45-minute kōrero and tour of the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
Tours are open to visitors of all ages (age 6+). Booking is not required.
Please meet at our waka reception desk on the ground floor before the start of the tour.
The ongoing struggle for equal rights
Come along to the National Library to learn about the journey New Zealand women took to gain the right to vote and about the ongoing struggle for equal rights.
View the 1893 petition that led to the creation of the Electoral Act 1893, which was signed into law on 19 September 1893.
Hear stories about wāhine toa like Meri Te Tai Mangakāhia (Te Rarawa) and suffragists Kate Sheppard, Ada Wells and maybe an ancestor of your own.
events.description:
Join our kaimahi for a special lunchtime tour and kōrero, highlighting the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition | Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine, which paved the way for women’s suffrage in Aotearoa.

-Created by our local quiz writer to test your knowledge and tickle your funny bone When: Friday 19 September Doors: 7.00pm | Quiz starts: 7.30pm Where: Ivy Bar, Wellington Cost: Free entry Prizes: -Over $200 worth of prizes -Mini-games and spot prizes throughout the night -Grand prize: $100 Bar Voucher + bragging rights for a month Teams: 4–6 players Bookings: Email steven@ivybar.co.nz with your team name and number of players, or use the sign-up form via the ticket link Bonus Fun: -Selina’s signature drag performances between rounds -Drink specials all night Accessibility: Ivy Bar’s main entrance has stairs, but we can arrange alternate access with notice.
Inclusivity: LGBTQIA+ friendly – all welcome (yes, even the straight ones).
Content Warning: R18 – adult themes, strong language, and dangerously smooth legs.

events.id: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents Louisa Williamson-Level 1/18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents Louisa Williamson
events.venue: Level 1/18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
The ninth concert in this series of Aotearoa composers features the multi-talented saxophonist/composer Louisa Williamson. Since completing a Masters of Music in Composition in 2020, she has released two albums of original music (What Dreams May Come and Groundwork). In 2023 Louisa won the APRA Best Jazz Composition Award for her piece Dream Within A Dream, and in 2024 Louisa received a composition commission from the Wellington Jazz Festival and headlined the festival with the new work, The Chasm Where We Fall Into Each Other.  Louisa has worked with L.A.B, Bret McKenzie, AJA, The Rodger Fox Big Band, Royal NZ Air Force Band, Trinity Roots and Lord Echo.
"This commission opportunity has come at a perfect time for me to process some recent grief and pain that’s inhabited my circles. Whilst composing this music, I’ve thought about ideas around mental health, specifically with youth in Aotearoa, and also honouring some friends who have passed. I think artists have the ability to turn heartbreak into beauty, and this music is an attempt at that. Although the inspiration which generated the music is heavy, the performance itself will hopefully feel light and reflective (turning heartbreak into beauty = darkness into light!), and will embrace and celebrate the talents of the musicians who are playing. I’ve brought together a beautiful group of people who I know will handle this music with care and fortitude"
Bryn van Vliet - alto/flute
Tyaan Singh - alto sax
Louisa Williamson - tenor/flute
Eilish Wilson - baritone sax
Sylvester Green - trumpet
Kaia Johnstone - trumpet
Kaito Walley - trombone
Jakob Elijas - trombone
Anna Lee - euphonium
Sam Zhu - tuba
Leonardo Coghini - piano
Jacob Hurst - bass
Max Sheehan - drums
The Jazz Orchestra Composer Series showcases original music for large jazz ensemble by New Zealand composers. Concerts take place every 1st and 3rd Friday of the month, from May to October, from 7pm. Tickets are $15, door sales $20.
Thanks to Creative New Zealand for their generous support.

Louisa has worked with L.A.B, Bret McKenzie, AJA, The Rodger Fox Big Band, Royal NZ Air Force Band, Trinity Roots and Lord Echo.
I think artists have the ability to turn heartbreak into beauty, and this music is an attempt at that.

events.id: Monthly Jazz Night: Les Tripes- Parisian Swing Trio-The Thistle Inn, 3 Mulgrave St, Thorndon, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Monthly Jazz Night: Les Tripes- Parisian Swing Trio
events.venue: The Thistle Inn, 3 Mulgrave St, Thorndon, Wellington
events.long_description:
Get ready for a night of irresistible rhythm and sizzling jazz!

Swing clarinetist Oscar Lavën, guitarist Adrian Jensen, and double-bass raconteur Robert Henderson are "Les Tripes" (french for "The Guts") ; a hard-working interpretation of the irresistibly heart-pumping film-noir sound of Django Reinhardt's Quintette du Hot Club de France. Lavën, Jensen and Henderson are professional musicians based in Wellington, and have honed their project through years of performance in venues large and small.

Les Tripes will have you tapping your feet and swinging along as they infuse each performance with passion, precision, and a touch of French flair.

Don’t miss the chance to experience a night of pure, swinging magic!

Book now to join us for a French inspired Set Menu from 5.30pm (served in one of our dining rooms) before moving out to the show.
2 courses $55.
BOOKINGS ESSENTIAL.
Email reservations@thistleinn.co.nz to book.

events.id: MAMIL 2: GOMIL-The Opera House, 111 - 113 Manners Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: MAMIL 2: GOMIL
events.venue: The Opera House, 111 - 113 Manners Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
One of New Zealand’s most successful plays of all time, MAMIL (Middle Aged Man in Lycra) is hitting the road in a national tour of the long-awaited sequel GOMIL (Grumpy Old Man in Lycra).

Starring acting legend Mark Hadlow ONZM (King Kong, The Hobbit, SNAG) and written and directed by Gregory Cooper (MAMIL, That Bloody Woman), GOMIL reunites this dream team who is directly responsible for causing laughter lines on the faces of over 70,000 people who saw MAMIL!

“Fast-paced and slick” - Theatreview

GOMIL follows the journey of Wayne, the founder and team leader of the men's cycling group in MAMIL. A lot has happened to Wayne over the last 10 years. He has retired, his son has moved to London with his grandchildren and Maggie, his wife of 49 years, passed away suddenly a year ago. For Wayne, his family and his work were his life. They were the source of his life's pleasure and purpose and now he is having to cope with the loss of both.

The only thing left to take his mind off the pain is cycling with his MAMIL friends, especially Bryan, the central character of MAMIL. But a panic attack mid-ride and a crash with catastrophic consequences leads to a crisis of cycling confidence and the inability to do the thing he loves the most.

Like MAMIL, it takes an array of characters to help the central character rediscover what is truly important when their life seems adrift and meaningless. A relentlessly positive Scottish counsellor, a philosophical Romanian personal trainer, Wayne’s new arch-enemy in the form of an ocker Ozzie retirement village owner who grinds his gears and yes, even Pinarello -- the Italian bike of Bryan’s and Wayne’s nightmares -- all wittingly and unwittingly help Wayne get back on the bike and realise he still has something to offer, he still has a purpose and most importantly a reason to get out of bed every morning aside from going for a piss.

“An engaging and earnest work of art, packed with

events.id: Martinborough Music Festival 2025-Martinborough Town Hall, 8 Texas St, Martinborough-Event Finder
events.name: Martinborough Music Festival 2025
events.venue: Martinborough Town Hall, 8 Texas St, Martinborough
events.long_description:
Bringing the world to Martinborough for chamber music in the heart of South Wairarapa.

Join us for four exciting concerts over three days, featuring stunning New Zealand and international artists including Natalia Lomeiko (violin), Yuri Zhislin (violin/viola), Matthias Balzat and Ashley Brown (cello), Jian Liu (piano), Wilma Smith and Donald Armstrong (violin), Simon Brew (saxophone) and Caroline Henbest (viola).

These artists will bring to life extraordinary works including Zoltán Kodály's Duo for Violin and Cello, Op. 7; JS Bach's Goldberg Variations for string trio; Shostakovich's Piano Quintet in G minor, Op. 57 and Mozart's String Quintet No. 5 in D major, K.593.

The Sunday afternoon concert will also include the world premiere of Shifting Worlds, a piano quintet by renowned New Zealand composer Louise Webster, who has special ties with South Wairarapa.

Visit martinboroughmusicfestival.co.nz for more information about artists, programmes and links to ticket sales.

events.id: Lacuna Presents - Us Two tickets-Meow Nui, Wellington, New Zealand-Ticketek
events.name: Lacuna Presents - Us Two tickets
events.venue: Meow Nui, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Presented by: Lacuna
Us Two is a high-energy house DJ act from the Midlands, UK, with releases on some of the world's most respected labels including Knee Deep In Sound, MicroHertz, and Eastenderz. Known for deep grooves, rolling basslines, and infectious crowd connection, Us Two has earned support from global heavyweights like Marco Carola, Jamie Jones, and Skream.
From European festival stages to Ibiza's 528 for a standout set with Knee Deep In Sound, Us Two's sound blends underground credibility with dancefloor-ready energy.
His latest release, "Simulation" (featuring Franksy), drops on Pete Tong's TSZR label, and has already earned plays from tastemakers like ANOTR, SG Lewis, LF SYSTEM, and SOSA, with early reactions going wild at Music On (Pacha Ibiza) and beyond.
For Lacuna, hosting Us Two’s debut in Wellington is about more than a headline — it's personal. We're thrilled to finally bring a dear friend's sound to our city and invite you to feel the energy first-hand on Saturday, 20 September 2025, at Meow Nui.
Packages

events.name: Mental Health First Aid Aotearoa
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Mental Health First Aid Aotearoa Mental Health First Aid is an evidence-based workshop which gives people the skills and confidence to have supportive conversations with their whānau, co-workers and community and help guide them to professional help if needed.
You must attend the full two days to be able to do the online assessment for accreditation.
If you choose not to be accredited, you will receive a certificate of participation if you attend the full course.
A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel.

events.long_description:
The Artisan Craft Market is a premium handmade event that takes place across various locations in the broader Wellington region. This high-quality market is designed to foster a welcoming and friendly atmosphere.

Our vision at Artisan Craft Market is to make the market accessible to those who appreciate shopping locally. We aim to provide a platform that supports local artisans, allowing them to showcase their meticulously crafted, high-quality products. By bringing the market directly to the people, we hope to celebrate and promote the unique talents of our community’s skilled artisans.

Come support local at our NEW market in Wainuiomata (Lower Hutt City)

events.id: Box of Birds-Tararua Tramping Club Inc., 4 Moncrieff St, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Box of Birds
events.venue: Tararua Tramping Club Inc., 4 Moncrieff St, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
When: 20th – 26th September 2025
Monday - Saturday 10am
No shows on Sundays
Hailed as "the cutest little show in Aotearoa" (Hamilton Arts Festival 2024), award-winning theatre company Birdlife Productions have created this gorgeous theatre show designed especially for ages 4 to 9 years, Including exquisite puppetry, live interactive songs, projection and the teaching of a waiata, this work reflects our transformative connection to nature. Peter is reluctant to stay with nanna in the school holidays because she lives in the country and doesn't have a TV but Nanna finds ways to engage Peter in her love of the forest, especially the precious manu, when they build a nesting box for Ruru together. Peter is excited to see if Ruru will make her home in the box, waiting patiently while many other birds arrive to check out the box first! And after all that waiting, Nanna takes Peter on an exciting night time forest walk to find Ruru - in the dark! The bird characters are all familiar New Zealand locals, such as piwakawaka, kereru, tui and ruru, and the story highlights the importance of supporting them and the different needs they may have. Teachers and Parents have been ecstatic about this show and hundreds of New Zealand children have been transfixed by it.
As quoted by Theatreview: “This is truly a New Zealand show for New Zealand children and all those young-at-heart”.


Prices are just $15.00 per person
Under 2's are free
Special $7 preview show on Saturday September 20th 2025!

events.id: Fabric-a-brac 2025-St Anne's Hall, 22 Emmett St, Newtown, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Fabric-a-brac 2025
events.venue: St Anne's Hall, 22 Emmett St, Newtown, Wellington
events.long_description:
Fabric-a-brac returns to Wellington for our second event in 2025!

The first Fabric-a-brac was held in Wellington 15 years ago - we're sew excited to still be here, bring the sewing community together and raising money for Mary Potter Hospice.
Fabric-a-brac is a fun fabric and sewing supplies market where you can shop for vintage and modern sewing and upholstery fabric, patterns, haberdashery and more. It brings the sewing community together to share stashes, stories and delight in our mutual love of textiles.
Fabric-a-brac is volunteer-run, and is a fundraiser for hospice - in Wellington this is Mary Potter Hospice. All profits from this event are donated to their work. We've raised $80,000 since our first event in 2009.
Selling fabric
If you have a stash you'd like to sell, you can come and take a stall. You pay a stallholder fee (which goes to Hospice) but anything you make on the day is yours to keep. Stalls are allocated via a ballot, which will take place closer to the time. Go to our website to find the form. Closes mid August.

If you have fabric, haberdashery or patterns you'd like to move on, but don't want to have a table, you can donate items. This will all go onto the hospice table on the day, and all profits will go to their wonderful work.
Fabric donation points
- Made Marion
- Mary Potter Hospice - you can take donations to the Mary Potter Hospice in Mein St, Newtown

Pop-up cafe
The fabulous cafe is back with all of its gorgeous volunteers and fab food. There will be tea, coffee and sweet treats for sale, so you can sit down and chat over your new projects and fabric purchases. All proceeds from the cafe also go to Hospice.
Buying fabric
Bring cash - most stallholders and the cafe will be selling by cash only.
We look forward to seeing our fabulous fabric and sewing community soon!
*Saturday September 20 2025
*St Anne's Parish Hall, Emmett Street, Newtown, Wellington

events.id: Ngaio Repair Cafe-Ngaio Union Church, 3 Kenya St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Ngaio Repair Cafe
events.venue: Ngaio Union Church, 3 Kenya St, Wellington
events.description:
Ngaio Repair Café, organised in and by Ngaio Union Church, is part of the worldwide Repair Café movement to cut down waste and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
Our local volunteer repairers will look at and try to fix all sorts of household gear: wooden, metal, electrical, electronic, pottery, computer, fabric, toys, clothing, beads, cardboard – as long as it’s small enough for you to bring.
One of our volunteers is a guitar repairer who can mend and tune any fretted instruments.
Another has an oilstone and will sharpen knives.
While you wait to have your item looked at, tea and coffee and cold drink are provided.
